Passage one: "I have to tell you, Brabantio, that your daughter has run off with a Moor tonight, with only a humble gondolier as their escort. I'm wondering if you knew about this and gave your blessing, or if this is news to you. If it is, you might want to check if she's indeed gone. Brabantio, clearly upset and recalling a disturbing dream, called for lights and his staff to look into the matter further.". Passage two: Sir, I will answer anything. But I beseech you,
If ’t be your pleasure, and most wise consent,
(As partly I find it is) that your fair daughter,
At this odd-even and dull watch o’ the night,
Transported with no worse nor better guard,
But with a knave of common hire, a gondolier,
To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor:
If this be known to you, and your allowance,
We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs.
But if you know not this, my manners tell me,
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That from the sense of all civility,
I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Your daughter (if you have not given her leave)
I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself:
If she be in her chamber or your house,
Let loose on me the justice of the state
For thus deluding you.
BRABANTIO.
Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper! Call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light, I say, light!. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.. Passage two: The text explores the challenges of precisely discerning ideas, attributing these difficulties to several factors. Our senses have limitations, our minds may lack sharpness, and we often rush our thinking. The ability to distinguish ideas accurately is crucial for clear judgment and reasoning.

The passage argues that having a quick wit and a good memory does not necessarily guarantee clear judgment or profound reasoning. Wit, while appealing, relies on the rapid assembly of pleasing ideas. In contrast, judgment involves the meticulous separation of distinct ideas. This distinction underscores the difference between the immediate charm of wit and the more painstaking process of judgment.

True understanding, the text suggests, requires more than just a superficial pleasure or quick grasp of ideas. It demands a deeper analysis. This process might not be as instantly gratifying as a witty remark, but it is essential for genuine comprehension and sound judgment.

In essence, the passage reminds us that the path to clear thinking and sound reasoning is not always the easiest or the most immediately satisfying. It requires effort, careful consideration, and a willingness to look beyond the surface appeal of ideas. In a world where quick responses and instant gratification are often valued, this reminder to engage in deeper analysis is particularly relevant.

Think of it like the difference between fast food and a home-cooked meal. Fast food is quick, easy, and often appealing, much like wit. But a home-cooked meal, while requiring more time and effort, offers a depth of flavor and nourishment that fast food cannot match. This is the kind of depth that judgment and true understanding provide. So, while wit has its place, it is judgment and deep reasoning that ultimately lead us to clearer thinking and better decisions.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.. Passage two: The text explores the challenges of precisely discerning ideas, attributing these difficulties to several factors. Our senses have limitations, our minds may lack sharpness, and we often rush our thinking. The ability to distinguish ideas accurately is crucial for clear judgment and reasoning.

The passage argues that having a quick wit and a good memory does not necessarily guarantee clear judgment or profound reasoning. Wit, while appealing, relies on the rapid assembly of pleasing ideas. In contrast, judgment involves the meticulous separation of distinct ideas. This distinction underscores the difference between the immediate charm of wit and the more painstaking process of judgment.

True understanding, the text suggests, requires more than just a superficial pleasure or quick grasp of ideas. It demands a deeper analysis. This process might not be as instantly gratifying as a witty remark, but it is essential for genuine comprehension and sound judgment.

In essence, the passage reminds us that the path to clear thinking and sound reasoning is not always the easiest or the most immediately satisfying. It requires effort, careful consideration, and a willingness to look beyond the surface appeal of ideas. In a world where quick responses and instant gratification are often valued, this reminder to engage in deeper analysis is particularly relevant.

Think of it like the difference between fast food and a home-cooked meal. Fast food is quick, easy, and often appealing, much like wit. But a home-cooked meal, while requiring more time and effort, offers a depth of flavor and nourishment that fast food cannot match. This is the kind of depth that judgment and true understanding provide. So, while wit has its place, it is judgment and deep reasoning that ultimately lead us to clearer thinking and better decisions.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: TAMBURLAINE. Now clear the triple region of the air,
And let the Majesty of Heaven behold
Their scourge and terror tread on emperors.
Smile, stars that reign'd at my nativity,
And dim the brightness of your neighbour lamps;
Disdain to borrow light of Cynthia!
For I, the chiefest lamp of all the earth,
First rising in the east with mild aspect,
But fixed now in the meridian line,
Will send up fire to your turning spheres,
And cause the sun to borrow light of you.
My sword struck fire from his coat of steel,
Even in Bithynia, when I took this Turk;
As when a fiery exhalation,
Wrapt in the bowels of a freezing cloud,
Fighting for passage, make[s] the welkin crack,
And casts a flash of lightning to the earth:
But, ere I march to wealthy Persia,
Or leave Damascus and th' Egyptian fields,
As was the fame of Clymene's brain-sick son
That almost brent the axle-tree of heaven,
So shall our swords, our lances, and our shot
Fill all the air with fiery meteors;
Then, when the sky shall wax as red as blood,
It shall be said I made it red myself,
To make me think of naught but blood and war.
ZABINA. Unworthy king, that by thy cruelty
Unlawfully usurp'st the Persian seat,
Dar'st thou, that never saw an emperor
Before thou met my husband in the field,
Being thy captive, thus abuse his state,
Keeping his kingly body in a cage,
That roofs of gold and sun-bright palaces
Should have prepar'd to entertain his grace?
And treading him beneath thy loathsome feet,
Whose feet the kings of Africa have kiss'd?. She denounced him for illegally seizing the Persian throne and abusing her captive husband, who was once a highly respected emperor.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: Pandarus, determined to bring Troilus and Cressida together, persuaded Deiphobus, Troilus' brother, to invite Cressida to dinner under the pretense that she needed protection from Polyphete. Deiphobus agreed and got Hector and Helen on board with the plan. Meanwhile, Pandarus instructed Troilus to stay at Deiphobus' house, feigning illness.

At the dinner, Helen and Pandarus sang Troilus' praises, making Cressida feel proud to be the object of his affection. Seizing the opportunity, Pandarus suggested that Cressida should explain her situation directly to Troilus. To create a private moment for the couple, Pandarus arranged for Helen and Deiphobus to be occupied with some documents. He then led Cressida to Troilus, who was anxiously preparing to confess his love to her for the very first time.

The stage was set for a pivotal moment between Troilus and Cressida, thanks to the strategic maneuvers of Pandarus. The atmosphere was filled with anticipation as Troilus readied himself to express his deep feelings, hoping that this would be the beginning of something beautiful between them.. Passage two: Pandarus has other intentions; and, while Troilus writes daily letters with increasing love, he contrives the means of an interview. Seeking out Deiphobus, the brother of Troilus, he tells him that Cressida is in danger of violence from Polyphete, and asks protection for her. Deiphobus gladly complies, promises the protection of Hector and Helen, and goes to invite Cressida to dinner on the morrow. Meantime Pandarus instructs Troilus to go to the house of Deiphobus, plead an access of his fever for remaining all night, and keep his chamber next day. “Lo,” says the crafty promoter of love, borrowing a phrase from the hunting-field; “Lo, hold thee at thy tristre close, and I shall well the deer unto thy bowe drive.” Unsuspicious of stratagem, Cressida comes to dinner; and at table, Helen, Pandarus, and others, praise the absent Troilus, until “her heart laughs” for very pride that she has the love of such a knight. After dinner they speak of Cressida’s business; all confirm Deiphobus’ assurances of protection and aid; and Pandarus suggests that, since Troilus is there, Cressida shall herself tell him her case. Helen and Deiphobus alone accompany Pandarus to Troilus’ chamber; there Troilus produces some documents relating to the public weal, which Hector has sent for his opinion; Helen and Deiphobus, engrossed in perusal and discussion, roam out of the chamber, by a stair, into the garden; while Pandarus goes down to the hall, and, pretending that his brother and Helen are still with Troilus, brings Cressida to her lover. The Second Book leaves Pandarus whispering in his niece’s ear counsel to be merciful and kind to her lover, that hath for her such pain; while Troilus lies “in a kankerdort,” hearing the whispering without, and wondering what he shall say for this “was the first time that he should her pray of love; O! mighty God! what shall he say?”. Passage one: In a past fueled by pride and ambition, the former King of Denmark slayed Norway's King Fortinbras in battle and seized his lands through a treaty. Now, the young Fortinbras, driven by a desire to reclaim his father's territory, has assembled a band of reckless warriors to launch an offensive against Denmark. This looming threat has put Denmark on high alert, sparking extensive military preparations and heightened surveillance across the kingdom. The specter of young Fortinbras's impending attack hangs heavy over the Danish realm, shaping its current state of vigilance and defense.. Passage two: At least, the whisper goes so. Our last King,
Whose image even but now appear’d to us,
Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
Thereto prick’d on by a most emulate pride,
Dar’d to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet,
For so this side of our known world esteem’d him,
Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal’d compact,
Well ratified by law and heraldry,
Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
Which he stood seiz’d of, to the conqueror;
Against the which, a moiety competent
Was gaged by our King; which had return’d
To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he been vanquisher; as by the same cov’nant
And carriage of the article design’d,
His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
Of unimproved mettle, hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
Shark’d up a list of lawless resolutes,
For food and diet, to some enterprise
That hath a stomach in’t; which is no other,
As it doth well appear unto our state,
But to recover of us by strong hand
And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
So by his father lost. And this, I take it,
Is the main motive of our preparations,
The source of this our watch, and the chief head
Of this post-haste and rummage in the land.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Whose image even but now appear’d to us,
Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
Thereto prick’d on by a most emulate pride,
Dar’d to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet,
For so this side of our known world esteem’d him,
Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal’d compact,
Well ratified by law and heraldry,
Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
Which he stood seiz’d of, to the conqueror;
Against the which, a moiety competent
Was gaged by our King; which had return’d
To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he been vanquisher; as by the same cov’nant
And carriage of the article design’d,
His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
Of unimproved mettle, hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
Shark’d up a list of lawless resolutes,
For food and diet, to some enterprise
That hath a stomach in’t; which is no other,
As it doth well appear unto our state,
But to recover of us by strong hand
And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
So by his father lost. And this, I take it,
Is the main motive of our preparations,
The source of this our watch, and the chief head

Passage one: DEMETRIUS.
I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.
Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?
The one I’ll slay, the other slayeth me.
Thou told’st me they were stol’n into this wood,
And here am I, and wode within this wood
Because I cannot meet with Hermia.
Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
HELENA.
You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant,
But yet you draw not iron, for my heart
Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,
And I shall have no power to follow you.
DEMETRIUS.
Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?
Or rather do I not in plainest truth
Tell you I do not, nor I cannot love you?
HELENA.
And even for that do I love you the more.
I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,
The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,
Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,
Unworthy as I am, to follow you.
What worser place can I beg in your love,
(And yet a place of high respect with me)
Than to be usèd as you use your dog?
DEMETRIUS.
Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;
For I am sick when I do look on thee.
HELENA.
And I am sick when I look not on you.. Passage two: In the heart of the woods, Demetrius was on a mission to find Lysander and Hermia. Helena, however, had other plans. She believed that being close to him, even in these painful circumstances, was better than not being with him at all. Passage one: In this scene from Shakespeare's 'Macbeth,' Macbeth has a secret meeting with two assassins. He brings up how Banquo has mistreated them in the past, stirring up their old resentment. He questions their endurance and courage, pushing them to go ahead with the plot to murder Banquo. Macbeth presents the assassination as a way for them to improve their status and gain his approval. "You've been wronged by Banquo, haven't you?" he reminds them. "He's been a burden on you, and yet you're taking it patiently. Is this what real men do? It's time to act. You know what needs to be done. Show some courage and seize this opportunity. Banquo is the only one standing in your way, and dealing with him will earn you my favor." Macbeth's words are manipulative, playing on their emotions and pride to drive them to commit the crime. He's essentially saying, "Prove yourselves and eliminate the barrier to your success. This is your chance to turn the tables and come out on top." It's a stark display of Macbeth's ruthless ambition and his willingness to use others to achieve his goals.. Passage two: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
FIRST MURDERER.
It was, so please your Highness.
MACBETH.
Well then, now
Have you consider’d of my speeches? Know
That it was he, in the times past, which held you
So under fortune, which you thought had been
Our innocent self? This I made good to you
In our last conference, pass’d in probation with you
How you were borne in hand, how cross’d, the instruments,
Who wrought with them, and all things else that might
To half a soul and to a notion craz’d
Say, “Thus did Banquo.”
FIRST MURDERER.
You made it known to us.
MACBETH.
I did so; and went further, which is now
Our point of second meeting. Do you find
Your patience so predominant in your nature,
That you can let this go? Are you so gospell’d,
To pray for this good man and for his issue,
Whose heavy hand hath bow’d you to the grave,
And beggar’d yours forever?
FIRST MURDERER.
We are men, my liege.
MACBETH.
Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men;
As hounds, and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,
Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept
All by the name of dogs: the valu’d file
Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,
The housekeeper, the hunter, every one
According to the gift which bounteous nature
Hath in him clos’d; whereby he does receive
Particular addition, from the bill
That writes them all alike: and so of men.
Now, if you have a station in the file,
Not i’ th’ worst rank of manhood, say’t;
And I will put that business in your bosoms,
Whose execution takes your enemy off,
Grapples you to the heart and love of us,
Who wear our health but sickly in his life,
Which in his death were perfect.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

The Sylphs thro' mystic mazes guide their way,
Thro' all the giddy circle they pursue,
And old impertinence expel by new.
What tender maid but must a victim fall
To one man's treat, but for another's ball?
When Florio speaks what virgin could withstand,
If gentle Damon did not squeeze her hand?
With varying vanities, from ev'ry part,
They shift the moving Toyshop of their heart;
Where wigs with wigs, with sword-knots sword-knots strive,
Beaux banish beaux, and coaches coaches drive.
This erring mortals Levity may call;
Oh blind to truth! the Sylphs contrive it all.
Of these am I, who thy protection claim,
A watchful sprite, and Ariel is my name.
Late, as I rang'd the crystal wilds of air,
In the clear Mirror of thy ruling Star
I saw, alas! some dread event impend,
Ere to the main this morning sun descend,
But heav'n reveals not what, or how, or where:
Warn'd by the Sylph, oh pious maid, beware!
This to disclose is all thy guardian can:
Beware of all, but most beware of Man!"
He said; when Shock, who thought she slept too long,
Leap'd up, and wak'd his mistress with his tongue.
'T was then, Belinda, if report say true,
Thy eyes first open'd on a Billet-doux;
Wounds, Charms, and Ardors were no sooner read,
But all the Vision vanish'd from thy head.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

The Sun first rises o'er the purpled main,

Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as those:
Favours to none, to all she smiles extends;
Oft she rejects, but never once offends.
Bright as the sun, her eyes the gazers strike,
And, like the sun, they shine on all alike.
Yet graceful ease, and sweetness void of pride,
Might hide her faults, if Belles had faults to hide:
If to her share some female errors fall,
Look on her face, and you'll forget 'em all.
This Nymph, to the destruction of mankind,
Nourish'd two Locks, which graceful hung behind
In equal curls, and well conspir'd to deck
With shining ringlets the smooth iv'ry neck.
Love in these labyrinths his slaves detains,
And mighty hearts are held in slender chains.
With hairy springes we the birds betray,
Slight lines of hair surprise the finny prey,
Fair tresses man's imperial race ensnare,
And beauty draws us with a single hair.
Th' advent'rous Baron the bright locks admir'd;
He saw, he wish'd, and to the prize aspir'd.
Resolv'd to win, he meditates the way,
By force to ravish, or by fraud betray;
For when success a Lover's toil attends,

Passage one: 柏子潭，位于深谷之底，潭水深黑，清澈见底。潭畔有五龙祠，传说皇帝曾于此祈雨，获雨而归。潭边有双燕洞与南白鸽洞，洞内景色奇美，令人流连忘返。潭西不远，有一清泉，泉水清澈如镜，旁有一座废弃的亭子，名曰“渐入佳境”。淳熙年间，地方官员张商卿等人咏此景，题诗于亭，其诗情景交融，令人神往。. Passage two: 东南有柏子潭。潭在深谷底，延袤亩余，色正深黑。即欧阳公赛龙处，上有五龙祠。皇上初龙飞，屯兵于滁，会旱暵，亲挟雕弓，注矢于潭者三，约三日雨，如期果大雨。及御宝历，为作栏楯护潭，且新其庙。庙侧有时若亭。濂坐亭上，问潭侧双燕洞及其南白鸽洞，以肆穷览，人无知者，乃止。复西行约三里许，有泉泻出于两山之间，分流而下，曰让泉，潺潺清澈，可鉴毛发。傍岸有亭曰“渐入佳境”，今已废，惟四大字勒崖石间。淳熙中郡守张商卿等题名尚存。. Passage one: 东晋太元年间，武陵一渔人，沿溪捕鱼，偶遇一片桃花林。林中花开正盛，香气扑鼻，渔人遂顺溪而入，见林尽处有一山洞。洞口虽狭，然洞内却别有洞天。渔人怀疑，遂入洞探寻，见洞内田园美丽，村民安居乐业，不知世间变化，与外界隔绝。渔人与村民交谈，得知此地自称世外桃源，村民皆不知外界之事。渔人心生向往，欲回村后告知世人。

渔人回村后，将此事告知太守。太守闻之，遂派人寻找此地，然未能再找到入口。南阳高士刘子骥闻讯，亦欲前往探寻，然未能成行。自此无人再寻找此地，世外桃源成为传说，流传于世。渔人之经历，亦成为后人津津乐道之谈资。此地虽未能再现，然其美丽与宁静，依旧在人们心中留下深刻印象。世外桃源，成为人们心中向往之地，象征着宁静与安乐，亦成为后世文人墨客笔下之美景。. Passage two: 晋太元中，武陵人捕鱼为业。缘溪行，忘路之远近。忽逢桃花林，夹岸数百步，中无杂树，芳草鲜美，落英缤纷。渔人甚异之，复前行，欲穷其林。林尽水源，便得一山，山有小口，仿佛若有光。便舍船，从口入。初极狭，才通人。复行数十步，豁然开朗。土地平旷，屋舍俨然，有良田、美池、桑竹之属。阡陌交通，鸡犬相闻。其中往来种作，男女衣着，悉如外人。黄发垂髫，并怡然自乐。见渔人，乃大惊，问所从来。具答之。便要还家，设酒杀鸡作食。村中闻有此人，咸来问讯。自云先世避秦时乱，率妻子邑人来此绝境，不复出焉，遂与外人间隔。问今是何世，乃不知有汉，无论魏晋。此人一一为具言所闻，皆叹惋。余人各复延至其家，皆出酒食。停数日，辞去。此中人语云：“不足为外人道也。”既出，得其船，便扶向路，处处志之。及郡下，诣太守，说如此。太守即遣人随其往，寻向所志，遂迷，不复得路。南阳刘子骥，高尚士也，闻之，欣然规往。未果，寻病终。后遂无问津者。. Passage one: 庆历四年春，滕子京被谪守巴陵郡。子京至，治理地方，政通人和，经年努力，重修岳阳楼，乃委托余作文以记之。

岳阳楼巍然屹立，洞庭湖浩渺无垠。登楼远眺，湖光山色，尽收眼底。晴日湖面澄澈如镜，水波粼粼，令人心旷神怡；阴雨天气，湖面雾气弥漫，水天一色，则令人感慨万千。

余立楼上，思古幽情，不禁感慨。古之仁人，心胸开阔，不以外物所喜，亦不以外物所忧。其心唯忧国事，心系天下，持先忧后乐之精神。若无此等仁人，余将与谁共鸣？

岳阳楼之壮丽，洞庭湖之广阔，皆为天地之奇观。然人之心境，方为万物之灵。吾辈当效古仁人，心忧天下，先忧后乐，方不负此生。若能如此，则岳阳楼之景，洞庭湖之美，皆为心中之盛景矣。. Passage two: 庆历四年春，滕子京谪守巴陵郡。越明年，政通人和，百废具兴，乃重修岳阳楼，增其旧制，刻唐贤今人诗赋于其上，属予作文以记之。予观夫巴陵胜状，在洞庭一湖。衔远山，吞长江，浩浩汤汤，横无际涯，朝晖夕阴，气象万千，此则岳阳楼之大观也，前人之述备矣。然则北通巫峡，南极潇湘，迁客骚人，多会于此，览物之情，得无异乎？若夫淫雨霏霏，连月不开，阴风怒号，浊浪排空，日星隐曜，山岳潜形，商旅不行，樯倾楫摧，薄暮冥冥，虎啸猿啼。登斯楼也，则有去国怀乡，忧谗畏讥，满目萧然，感极而悲者矣。至若春和景明，波澜不惊，上下天光，一碧万顷，沙鸥翔集，锦鳞游泳，岸芷汀兰，郁郁青青。而或长烟一空，皓月千里，浮光跃金，静影沉璧，渔歌互答，此乐何极！登斯楼也，则有心旷神怡，宠辱偕忘，把酒临风，其喜洋洋者矣。嗟夫！予尝求古仁人之心，或异二者之为，何哉？不以物喜，不以己悲，居庙堂之高则忧其民，处江湖之远则忧其君。是进亦忧，退亦忧。然则何时而乐耶？其必曰“先天下之忧而忧，后天下之乐而乐”乎！噫！微斯人，吾谁与归？时六年九月十五日。. Passage one: 滁州西南有琅琊山，其景致甚美。山峦叠翠，溪流潺潺，四时之景，各具风情。春日暖风拂面，花开烂漫，夏日绿树成荫，清泉汩汩，秋日红叶如火，果实累累，冬日雪花飘落，银装素裹。此山之美，实为人间胜境。

山中有亭，名曰醉翁亭。亭前溪水环绕，亭后翠竹掩映，亭中花木繁茂，鸟语花香，令人心旷神怡。太守欧阳修常与宾客至此饮酒娱乐，欣赏山水之美。酒至酣处，众人皆忘忧虑，达到忘我之境。

欧阳修善于文笔，其描绘山水之景，笔触细腻，情感真挚。他通过文字，表达了对山水乐趣的体会与理解。在他的笔下，琅琊山的美景如同一幅幅画卷，展现在读者面前。他写道：“山光水色，与人相宜，乐而忘忧，真乃人生一大乐事也。”

欧阳修不仅描绘了琅琊山的美景，更展现了人与自然的深刻联系。他认为，人生在世，当与自然和谐相处， method此可获得心灵的宁静与满足。他在醉翁亭中，与宾客共饮，观山赏水，心中无限愉悦。他写道：“醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。”

琅琊山的美景，醉翁亭的优雅，欧阳修的文笔，皆为后人所称道。他通过对山水的描绘，表达了对自然的热爱与敬畏，展现了人与自然和谐共处的美好愿景。欧阳修的文字，如同一股清泉，滋润着每一个读者的心田，令人心生向往，愿与自然共享美好时光。. Passage two: 环滁皆山也。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行六七里，渐闻水声潺潺，而泻出于两峰之间者，酿泉也。峰回路转，有亭翼然临于泉上者，醉翁亭也。作亭者谁？山之僧智仙也。名之者谁？太守自谓也。太守与客来饮于此，饮少辄醉，而年又最高，故自号曰醉翁也。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。若夫日出而林霏开，云归而岩穴暝，晦明变化者，山间之朝暮也。野芳发而幽香，佳木秀而繁阴，风霜高洁，水落而石出者，山间之四时也。朝而往，暮而归，四时之景不同，而乐亦无穷也。至于负者歌于途，行者休于树，前者呼，后者应，伛偻提携，往来而不绝者，滁人游也。临溪而渔，溪深而鱼肥，酿泉为酒，泉香而酒洌，山肴野蔌，杂然而前陈者，太守宴也。宴酣之乐，非丝非竹，射者中，弈者胜，觥筹交错，起坐而喧哗者，众宾欢也。苍颜白发，颓然乎其间者，太守醉也。已而夕阳在山，人影散乱，太守归而宾客从也。树林阴翳，鸣声上下，游人去而禽鸟乐也。然而禽鸟知山林之乐，而不知人之乐；人知从太守游而乐，而不知太守之乐其乐也。醉能同其乐，醒能述以文者，太守也。太守谓谁？庐陵欧阳修也。. Passage two: 滁州西南有琅琊山，其景致甚美。山峦叠翠，溪流潺潺，四时之景，各具风情。春日暖风拂面，花开烂漫，夏日绿树成荫，清泉汩汩，秋日红叶如火，果实累累，冬日雪花飘落，银装素裹。此山之美，实为人间胜境。

山中有亭，名曰醉翁亭。亭前溪水环绕，亭后翠竹掩映，亭中花木繁茂，鸟语花香，令人心旷神怡。太守欧阳修常与宾客至此饮酒娱乐，欣赏山水之美。酒至酣处，众人皆忘忧虑，达到忘我之境。

欧阳修善于文笔，其描绘山水之景，笔触细腻，情感真挚。他通过文字，表达了对山水乐趣的体会与理解。在他的笔下，琅琊山的美景如同一幅幅画卷，展现在读者面前。他写道：“山光水色，与人相宜，乐而忘忧，真乃人生一大乐事也。”

欧阳修不仅描绘了琅琊山的美景，更展现了人与自然的深刻联系。他认为，人生在世，当与自然和谐相处， method此可获得心灵的宁静与满足。他在醉翁亭中，与宾客共饮，观山赏水，心中无限愉悦。他写道：“醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。”

琅琊山的美景，醉翁亭的优雅，欧阳修的文笔，皆为后人所称道。他通过对山水的描绘，表达了对自然的热爱与敬畏，展现了人与自然和谐共处的美好愿景。欧阳修的文字，如同一股清泉，滋润着每一个读者的心田，令人心生向往，愿与自然共享美好时光。. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: 余告之曰：其形也，翩若惊鸿，婉若游龙。荣曜秋菊，华茂春松。髣髴兮若轻云之蔽月，飘飖兮若流风之回雪。远而望之，皎若太阳升朝霞；迫而察之，灼若芙蕖出渌波。穠纤得衷，修短合度。肩若削成，腰如约素。延颈秀项，皓质呈露。芳泽无加，铅华弗御。云髻峨峨，修眉联娟。丹唇外朗，皓齿内鲜。明眸善睐，靥辅承权。瓌姿艳逸，仪静体闲。柔情绰态，媚于语言。奇服旷世，骨像应图。披罗衣之璀粲兮，珥瑶碧之华琚。戴金翠之首饰，缀明珠以耀躯。践远游之文履，曳雾绡之轻裾。微幽兰之芳蔼兮，步踟蹰于山隅。于是忽焉纵体，以遨以嬉。左倚采旄，右荫桂旗。攘皓腕于神浒兮，采湍濑之玄芝。. Passage two: 有女子，姿容绝世，宛若天人。其形态优美，如轻盈鸿鹤，又似游动之龙，令人望而生畏。脸色光彩照人，姿态潇洒，风华绝代。其服饰精美绝伦，配饰华丽，举手投足之间，尽显高雅气质。眉如远山，目若秋水，顾盼生辉，惊为天人。肌肤胜雪，柔若无骨，步态轻盈，宛如仙子下凡。微微一笑，百媚俱生，令人心醉神迷。其美貌、气质、服饰，无一不让人惊叹，实乃世间罕见之美人也。. Passage one: 天地之间，正气浩荡，其形虽异，其质则一。昊天罔极，苍穹无垠，正气化为日月星辰，照耀四方；大地辽阔，山河壮丽，正气蕴于草木鱼虫，生机盎然。人间则浩然之气，充塞宇宙，无处不在。自古仁人志士，皆依正气而行，为国捐躯，修身齐家，其行其事，虽历千秋，犹如昨日，不朽不灭。

余自幼薄命，命途多舛，今身陷囹圄，然心怀正气，未尝稍懈。窃思天地之正气，非一朝一夕之功，乃积德累善，方能弘扬。余虽处困厄，然志不可夺，信不可屈。正气在胸，则胸怀天下，心怀正义，则正义必胜。

吾辈应以正气为纲，修身齐家，治国平天下。凡事皆有因果，善恶终有报。余虽身处牢笼，然心向光明，信于未来，必有柳暗花明之时。正气长存，则道德永恒，高尚人格，必将弘扬于世。愿天下仁人志士，皆能追求正气，共同弘扬正义与道德，使天地之间，正气长存，浩然之气，充塞宇宙。. Passage one: 于是张良至军门见樊哙。樊哙曰：“今日之事何如？”良曰：“甚急！今者项庄拔剑舞，其意常在沛公也。”哙曰：“此迫矣！臣请入，与之同命。”哙即带剑拥盾入军门。交戟之卫士欲止不内，樊哙侧其盾以撞，卫士仆地，哙遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目视项王，头发上指，目眦尽裂。项王按剑而跽曰：“客何为者？”张良曰：“沛公之参乘樊哙者也。”项王曰：“壮士！赐之卮酒。”则与斗卮酒。哙拜谢，起，立而饮之。项王曰：“赐之彘肩。”则与一生彘肩。樊哙覆其盾于地，加彘肩上，拔剑切而啖之。项王曰：“壮士！能复饮乎？”樊哙曰：“臣死且不避，卮酒安足辞！夫秦王有虎狼之心，杀人如不能举，刑人如恐不胜，天下皆叛之。怀王与诸将约曰：‘先破秦入咸阳者王之。’今沛公先破秦入咸阳，毫毛不敢有所近，封闭宫室，还军霸上，以待大王来。故遣将守关者，备他盗出入与非常也。劳苦而功高如此，未有封侯之赏，而听细说，欲诛有功之人，此亡秦之续耳。窃为大王不取也！”项王未有以应，曰：“坐。”樊哙从良坐。坐须臾，沛公起如厕，因招樊哙出。. Passage two: 张良见樊哙，急告之曰：“事急矣，项庄舞剑，意在沛公。”樊哙闻之，心中大惊，决意进入宴会，与沛公同生死。于是，樊哙强行入内，直至项王面前，拱手曰：“臣闻沛公有大功于天下，然项王待之不公。沛公入关，约法三章，深得民心；又率先入咸阳，封宫室库府，财物分毫不取，此皆沛公之功也。今项王以此待沛公，臣愿与沛公共之。”

项王闻言，默然无语。樊哙遂与张良坐于沛公之旁，以防不测。沛公见势，起身曰：“吾欲如厕。”遂招樊哙同行，二人乃借此离去。樊哙随沛公出，心中暗喜，知沛公暂无危险。然心中仍存忧虑，虑项王终有变故。

宴会之中，项王虽未再言语，然心中亦有所触动。樊哙之言，犹如利剑，直指项王之心。项王虽未明言，然对沛公之态度，亦有所缓和。沛公与樊哙离去后，项王未再追究，宴会乃得以继续。然此事终为后世所传，樊哙之勇，沛公之智，皆为人所敬仰。. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage two: 于是张良至军门见樊哙。樊哙曰：“今日之事何如？”良曰：“甚急！今者项庄拔剑舞，其意常在沛公也。”哙曰：“此迫矣！臣请入，与之同命。”哙即带剑拥盾入军门。交戟之卫士欲止不内，樊哙侧其盾以撞，卫士仆地，哙遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目视项王，头发上指，目眦尽裂。项王按剑而跽曰：“客何为者？”张良曰：“沛公之参乘樊哙者也。”项王曰：“壮士！赐之卮酒。”则与斗卮酒。哙拜谢，起，立而饮之。项王曰：“赐之彘肩。”则与一生彘肩。樊哙覆其盾于地，加彘肩上，拔剑切而啖之。项王曰：“壮士！能复饮乎？”樊哙曰：“臣死且不避，卮酒安足辞！夫秦王有虎狼之心，杀人如不能举，刑人如恐不胜，天下皆叛之。怀王与诸将约曰：‘先破秦入咸阳者王之。’今沛公先破秦入咸阳，毫毛不敢有所近，封闭宫室，还军霸上，以待大王来。故遣将守关者，备他盗出入与非常也。劳苦而功高如此，未有封侯之赏，而听细说，欲诛有功之人，此亡秦之续耳。窃为大王不取也！”项王未有以应，曰：“坐。”樊哙从良坐。坐须臾，沛公起如厕，因招樊哙出。. Passage one: 咸平二年，岁在壬辰，有女子嫁与府吏为妻。夫妇伉俪情深，然府吏之母，性情孤僻，不喜女子，常以言语相讥。女子性柔和，唯以忍耐为要，然心中煎熬，日夜难安。

一日，女子实在不堪忍受，遂向府吏提出欲归家之意。府吏闻之，心中大惊，极力反对，然女子心意已决，难以改变。府吏无奈，只得向母亲陈情，曰：“母亲大人，儿与妻子情深意笃，愿母亲宽容，莫再责难。”

然母亲性情执拗，听闻府吏之言，怒而曰：“此女非我所愿，何必强留？”府吏见母亲态度坚决，心中悲愤，然亦无力回天。

女子见事已至此，心中悲凉，遂决意离去。临行之际，女子对府吏曰：“夫君，妾与君相识相恋，曾以为此生足矣。然今日之事，实非妾所愿，然亦无可奈何。愿君珍重，妾此去，或许永不相见。”

府吏闻言，泪如雨下，曰：“妻子，吾心亦痛，然母命难违，吾亦无能为力。妻子此去，吾定日夜思念，望妻子亦自珍重。”

女子离家之日，府吏相送至门外，目送女子远去，心中悲痛难抑。女子回首望向府吏，眼中含泪，心中思绪万千。往昔岁月，仿佛历历在目，然今日之别，却如天人永隔。

女子归家后，心中常思夫妇之情，然知此生已无缘再续。每当夜深人静之时，女子常独坐窗前，望月怀人，心中无尽遗憾。而府吏亦日夜思念女子，然母命难违，只得将心中之情深藏心底。

岁月荏苒，女子与府吏虽各自安好，然心中之痛，却如影随形，难以释怀。往昔之情，终成回忆，唯有对未来的无奈，成为二人心中永恒的痛。. Passage two: “十三能织素，十四学裁衣。十五弹箜篌，十六诵诗书。十七为君妇，心中常苦悲。君既为府吏，守节情不移。贱妾留空房，相见常日稀。鸡鸣入机织，夜夜不得息。三日断五匹，大人故嫌迟。非为织作迟，君家妇难为！妾不堪驱使，徒留无所施。便可白公姥，及时相遣归。” 府吏得闻之，堂上启阿母：“儿已薄禄相，幸复得此妇。结发同枕席，黄泉共为友。共事二三年，始尔未为久。女行无偏斜，何意致不厚。” 阿母谓府吏：“何乃太区区！此妇无礼节，举动自专由。吾意久怀忿，汝岂得自由！东家有贤女，自名秦罗敷。可怜体无比，阿母为汝求。便可速遣之，遣去慎莫留！” 府吏长跪告：“伏惟启阿母。今若遣此妇，终老不复取！” 阿母得闻之，槌床便大怒：“小子无所畏，何敢助妇语！吾已失恩义，会不相从许！” 府吏默无声，再拜还入户。举言谓新妇，哽咽不能语：“我自不驱卿，逼迫有阿母。卿但暂还家，吾今且报府。不久当归还，还必相迎取。以此下心意，慎勿违吾语。” 新妇谓府吏：“勿复重纷纭。往昔初阳岁，谢家来贵门。奉事循公姥，进止敢自专？昼夜勤作息，伶俜萦苦辛。谓言无罪过，供养卒大恩；仍更被驱遣，何言复来还！妾有绣腰襦，葳蕤自生光；红罗复斗帐，四角垂香囊；箱帘六七十，绿碧青丝绳，物物各自异，种种在其中。人贱物亦鄙，不足迎后人，留待作遗施，于今无会因。时时为安慰，久久莫相忘！”. Passage one: 余以乾隆三十九年十二月，自京师乘风雪，历齐河、长清，穿泰山西北谷，越长城之限，至于泰安。是月丁未，与知府朱孝纯子颍由南麓登。四十五里，道皆砌石为磴，其级七千有余。泰山正南面有三谷。中谷绕泰安城下，郦道元所谓环水也。余始循以入，道少半，越中岭，复循西谷，遂至其巅。古时登山，循东谷入，道有天门。东谷者，古谓之天门溪水，余所不至也。今所经中岭及山巅，崖限当道者，世皆谓之天门云。道中迷雾冰滑，磴几不可登。及既上，苍山负雪，明烛天南。望晚日照城郭，汶水、徂徕如画，而半山居雾若带然。 戊申晦，五鼓，与子颍坐日观亭，待日出。大风扬积雪击面。亭东自足下皆云漫。稍见云中白若樗蒱数十立者，山也。极天云一线异色，须臾成五采。日上，正赤如丹，下有红光动摇承之。或曰，此东海也。回视日观以西峰，或得日或否，绛皓驳色，而皆若偻。 亭西有岱祠，又有碧霞元君祠。皇帝行宫在碧霞元君祠东。是日观道中石刻，自唐显庆以来；其远古刻尽漫失。僻不当道者，皆不及往。 山多石，少土。石苍黑色，多平方，少圜。少杂树，多松，生石罅，皆平顶。冰雪，无瀑水，无鸟兽音迹。至日观数里内无树，而雪与人膝齐。 桐城姚鼐记。. Passage two: 乾隆三十九年冬，余自京城出发，冒严寒，踏冰雪，途经多地，最终抵达泰山。此行所见所闻，皆为平生未曾经历，故欣然记之。

初自京城出发，经由天津、德州、济南等地，虽路途遥远，然景色各异，令人心旷神怡。德州之地，田野辽阔，农人忙碌于田间，景象颇为壮观。济南之地，泉水清澈，古桥横跨，仿若人间仙境。

行至泰山脚下，登山之路艰险而曲折。山道狭窄，坡陡石滑，稍有不慎，便有失足之险。然道中景色，却令人流连忘返。山间松柏，郁郁葱葱，冬雪未消，冰挂于枝头，银装素裹，如诗如画。

登山途中，经过红门宫、斗母宫等古建筑，皆为历史悠久，石刻文字，记载着历代帝王与文人墨客的诗句与题记。每一处古迹，皆令人驻足流连，感慨万千。

登至山顶，天色将明，遥望东方，日出之景，壮丽无比。初时，天际微亮，继而红霞满天，太阳冉冉升起，照耀大地，万物复苏，景象蔚为壮观。泰山之顶，云雾缭绕，仿若仙境，令人心生敬仰。

泰山之自然环境，更是独具特色。山石嶙峋，形态各异，有如天工雕琢。树木参天，古藤缠绕，冬雪覆盖，晶莹剔透。山间小径，曲折蜿蜒，行走其间，仿若进入另一世界。

此行泰山，虽历经艰辛，然所见所闻，皆为平生难得之经历。泰山之美，非笔墨所能尽述，唯有亲身体验，方能感受其中之妙。回首此行，心中充满感慨，亦对大自然之美，更加敬仰。

Passage one: Bleed, bleed, poor country!
Great tyranny, lay thou thy basis sure,
For goodness dare not check thee! wear thou thy wrongs;
The title is affeer’d.—Fare thee well, lord:
I would not be the villain that thou think’st
For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp
And the rich East to boot.
MALCOLM.
Be not offended:
I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
I think our country sinks beneath the yoke;
It weeps, it bleeds; and each new day a gash
Is added to her wounds. I think, withal,
There would be hands uplifted in my right;
And here, from gracious England, have I offer
Of goodly thousands: but, for all this,
When I shall tread upon the tyrant’s head,
Or wear it on my sword, yet my poor country
Shall have more vices than it had before,
More suffer, and more sundry ways than ever,
By him that shall succeed.. Passage two: The nation lies in ruins, its people crushed under the weight of tyrannical rule. Everywhere one looks, there are signs of oppression and deep wounds that mar the once-prosperous land. Despite the allure of power, I find myself hesitant to embrace villainy, even as others succumb to its temptations.

Malcolm, observing the devastation, acknowledges the depth of our country's suffering. He speaks of potential aid from England, a glimmer of hope in our darkest hour. Yet, he cautions that overthrowing our current despot may not be the end of our troubles. The next ruler, he warns, could bring with them a host of new vices and hardships, perhaps even worse than those we endure now.

As we stand at this crossroads, we must carefully consider our path forward. The promise of change is enticing, but we must be wary of trading one tyrant for another, lest we find ourselves longing for the devil we knew.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: CHORUS. When Faustus had with pleasure ta’en the view
Of rarest things, and royal courts of kings,
He stay’d his course, and so returned home;
Where such as bear his absence but with grief,
I mean his friends and near’st companions,
Did gratulate his safety with kind words,
And in their conference of what befell,
Touching his journey through the world and air,
They put forth questions of astrology,
Which Faustus answer’d with such learned skill
As they admir’d and wonder’d at his wit.
Now is his fame spread forth in every land:
Amongst the rest the Emperor is one,
Carolus the Fifth, at whose palace now
Faustus is feasted ’mongst his noblemen.
What there he did, in trial of his art,
I leave untold; your eyes shall see[’t] perform’d.. Passage two: After his grand adventures through exotic lands and royal courts, Faustus finally returned home. His friends and companions greeted him with unbridled enthusiasm, eager to hear tales of his travels. As they gathered, the conversation turned to the intricate subject of astrology. Faustus, drawing upon his vast knowledge, spoke with such eloquence and depth that all present were left in awe. His mastery of the subject only served to further elevate his already considerable reputation.

Passage one: No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
URSULA.
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
HERO.
So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord.
URSULA.
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
HERO.
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
URSULA.
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
HERO.. Passage two: Hero and Ursula sat in the garden, discussing the latest gossip about Beatrice and Benedick. "Are you certain Benedick truly loves her?" Ursula asked skeptically. Hero nodded, "The Prince and Claudio told me so themselves. They wanted me to tell Beatrice, but I advised against it." Ursula furrowed her brow, "Why would you do that? Surely Benedick deserves someone as witty and beautiful as Beatrice." Hero sighed, "I fear Beatrice's sharp tongue might wound Benedick's pride. It's better to let their feelings develop naturally." Ursula considered this, then smiled mischievously, "Perhaps we could give them a little nudge in the right direction?" The two women exchanged knowing glances, their minds already plotting.. And promised to be at his commaund:

That Guise ch, durst stand in armes against the King,
For not effecting of his holines will.

Passage one: Hung with hard ice-flakes, where hail-scur flew,
There I heard naught save the harsh sea
And ice-cold wave, at whiles the swan cries,
Did for my games the gannet’s clamour,
Sea-fowls, loudness was for me laughter,
The mews' singing all my mead-drink.
Storms, on the stone-cliffs beaten, fell on the stern
In icy feathers; full oft the eagle screamed
With spray on his pinion.
Not any protector
May make merry man faring needy.
This he little believes, who aye in winsome life
Abides ’mid burghers some heavy business,
Wealthy and wine-flushed, how I weary oft
Must bide above brine.. Passage two: The seafarer's life is one of unrelenting hardship. Alone on the vast, unforgiving ocean, he battles against icy winds and towering waves. Passage one: My heart aches for Wulf, my beloved, who dwells on a distant island. I fear for his safety among those who wish him harm. Each day without him is a torment, my thoughts consumed by worry and longing. When he does come to me, our moments together are bittersweet. His strong arms around me bring comfort, yet I know our time is fleeting. Too soon, he must leave again, and I am left with only memories to sustain me. The rarity of his visits only deepens my sorrow. I wonder if he truly understands the depth of my feelings, or if our love is as fragile as morning dew. Sometimes I fear that our bond, stretched thin by distance and circumstance, may snap like a thread. Oh Wulf, will we ever find lasting happiness together, or are we doomed to this cycle of brief joy and prolonged heartache?. Passage two: It's as if someone should give a gift to my people—
they will kill him if he comes to the troop.
It is otherwise for us.
Wulf is on an island, I on another.
Fast is that island, surrounded by fen.
The men on the island are murderous and cruel;
they will kill him if he comes to the troop.
It is otherwise for us.
I felt far-wandering hopes for my Wulf,
as I sat weeping in the rainy weather,
when the bold warrior's arms embraced me—
it was sweet to me, yet I also despised it.
Wulf, my Wulf! My wanting you
has made me sick—your seldom coming,
my mourning heart, not lack of meat.
Do you hear, Eadwacer? A wolf bears away
our wretched cub to the woods.
One can easily split what was never united,
the song of the two of us.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Simply possessing a vague, muddled perception of things is not enough to truly understand them. Often, we mistakenly attribute these universal propositions to innate knowledge, when in fact, their widespread acceptance stems from our mind's ability to perceive similarities and differences between concepts with clarity. It is through this process of careful distinction that we can move beyond superficial understanding and delve into the depths of true knowledge. By honing this skill of discernment, we unlock the potential to grasp complex ideas and unravel the intricacies of the world around us.. Passage two: Another faculty we may take notice of in our minds is that of DISCERNING and DISTINGUISHING between the several ideas it has. It is not enough to have a confused perception of something in general. Unless the mind had a distinct perception of different objects and their qualities, it would be capable of very little knowledge, though the bodies that affect us were as busy about us as they are now, and the mind were continually employed in thinking. On this faculty of distinguishing one thing from another depends the evidence and certainty of several, even very general, propositions, which have passed for innate truths;—because men, overlooking the true cause why those propositions find universal assent, impute it wholly to native uniform impressions; whereas it in truth depends upon this clear discerning faculty of the mind, whereby it PERCEIVES two ideas to be the same, or different. Passage one: But tell me now, how hast thou spent thy time?
ITHAMORE. Faith, master,
In setting Christian villages on fire,
haining of eunuchs, binding galley-slaves.
One time I was an hostler in an inn,
And in the night-time secretly would I steal
To travellers' chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneel'd,
I strewed powder on the marble stones,
And therewithal their knees would rankle so,
That I have laugh'd a-good to see the cripples
Go limping home to Christendom on stilts.
BARABAS. Why, this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villains both;
Both circumcised; we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret; thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside; here comes Don Lodowick.. Passage two: Ithamore, with a gleam in his eye, regaled Barabas with tales of his wicked past. Passage one: In the dawn of creation, a tale unfolds that echoes through the ages—a story of paradise lost and humanity's fall from grace. This narrative begins with Adam and Eve, the first of our kind, dwelling in the perfect garden of Eden. Blessed with abundance and divine favor, they lived in harmony with their Creator and all of nature.

Yet, in a moment that would forever alter the course of human history, they succumbed to temptation. Defying the explicit command of God, they partook of the forbidden fruit, an act of disobedience that shattered the idyllic existence they had known. This single choice ushered in death, suffering, and the loss of their heavenly home.

As we embark on this poetic journey, we seek to understand the profound consequences of that fateful decision. What compelled our ancestors to risk everything for a taste of forbidden knowledge? How did their actions reshape the relationship between humanity and the divine?

To unravel these mysteries, we call upon the Heavenly Muse and the Holy Spirit for inspiration. May their divine wisdom guide our words as we strive to illuminate the complex interplay of free will, temptation, and divine justice.

Through this exploration, we aim to shed light on God's ways, making them comprehensible to mortal minds. We seek not to judge, but to understand—to find meaning in the suffering that followed and to glimpse the possibility of redemption that lies beyond the fall.. Passage two: Of Man’s first disobedience, and the fruit
Of that forbidden tree whose mortal taste
Brought death into the World, and all our woe,
With loss of Eden, till one greater Man
Restore us, and regain the blissful seat,
Sing, Heavenly Muse, that, on the secret top
Of Oreb, or of Sinai, didst inspire
That shepherd who first taught the chosen seed
In the beginning how the heavens and earth
Rose out of Chaos: or, if Sion hill
Delight thee more, and Siloa’s brook that flowed
Fast by the oracle of God, I thence
Invoke thy aid to my adventurous song,
That with no middle flight intends to soar
Above th’ Aonian mount, while it pursues
Things unattempted yet in prose or rhyme.
And chiefly thou, O Spirit, that dost prefer
Before all temples th’ upright heart and pure,
Instruct me, for thou know’st; thou from the first
Wast present, and, with mighty wings outspread,
Dove-like sat’st brooding on the vast Abyss,
And mad’st it pregnant: what in me is dark
Illumine, what is low raise and support;
That, to the height of this great argument,
I may assert Eternal Providence,
And justify the ways of God to men.
Say first—for Heaven hides nothing from thy view,
Nor the deep tract of Hell—say first what cause
Moved our grand parents, in that happy state,
Favoured of Heaven so highly, to fall off
From their Creator, and transgress his will
For one restraint, lords of the World besides.
Who first seduced them to that foul revolt?. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: Sir, I will answer anything. But I beseech you,
If ’t be your pleasure, and most wise consent,
(As partly I find it is) that your fair daughter,
At this odd-even and dull watch o’ the night,
Transported with no worse nor better guard,
But with a knave of common hire, a gondolier,
To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor:
If this be known to you, and your allowance,
We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs.
But if you know not this, my manners tell me,
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That from the sense of all civility,
I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Your daughter (if you have not given her leave)
I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself:
If she be in her chamber or your house,
Let loose on me the justice of the state
For thus deluding you.
BRABANTIO.
Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper! Call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light, I say, light!. Passage two: In the dead of night, a frantic messenger arrives at Brabantio's door, bearing shocking news. "Sir," he exclaims, "your daughter has fled with a Moor! They've eloped under cover of darkness, with only a common gondolier to guide their escape." The messenger, his voice tinged with urgency, presses further, "Did you know of this? Have you given your blessing? If not, I implore you to check her chambers at once!"

Brabantio, his face pale with shock, feels a chill run down his spine. The words of the messenger eerily echo a disturbing dream that had plagued his sleep recently. Could it be that his nightmares have manifested into reality? His mind races, grappling with the implications of this news.

"Lights!" he bellows, his voice cracking with emotion. "Bring me lights at once!" The household stirs, awakened by their master's distress. Brabantio calls for his attendants, determined to uncover the truth. "Search every corner of the house!" he commands, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and anger. As the servants scramble to obey, Brabantio steels himself for what he might discover, praying that this alarming report is nothing more than a cruel jest or a misunderstanding.. If this be known to you, and your allowance,
We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs.
But if you know not this, my manners tell me,
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That from the sense of all civility,
I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Your daughter (if you have not given her leave)
I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself:
If she be in her chamber or your house,
Let loose on me the justice of the state
For thus deluding you.
BRABANTIO.
Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper! Call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already.

Passage one: In our quest for knowledge and understanding, we often encounter significant challenges when attempting to discern and differentiate between ideas. This difficulty stems from various sources, including the inherent limitations of our sensory perceptions, a lack of mental acuity, and our tendency towards hasty conclusions. The ability to accurately distinguish between concepts is crucial for clear judgment and sound reasoning, yet it remains an elusive skill for many.

It is worth noting that individuals blessed with quick wit and exceptional memory are not necessarily endowed with the clearest judgment or the most profound capacity for reason. Wit, in its essence, relies on the rapid assembly of agreeable ideas, creating connections that may be entertaining or clever but not always substantive. In contrast, judgment involves a more meticulous process of separating and analyzing distinct ideas, often requiring greater effort and time.

The immediate appeal of wit can be seductive, offering instant gratification and social approval. A witty remark or clever association can elicit laughter or admiration, providing a sense of intellectual satisfaction. However, this satisfaction is often superficial and fleeting. True understanding and wisdom demand a deeper, more thorough examination of ideas and their relationships.

Judgment, on the other hand, is a laborious process that may not yield immediate rewards. It requires patience, careful consideration, and the ability to resist the allure of quick, surface-level connections. The judicious mind must sift through information, weigh evidence, and consider multiple perspectives before arriving at a conclusion. This process can be time-consuming and mentally taxing, but it is essential for developing a nuanced understanding of complex issues.

The contrast between wit and judgment highlights a fundamental tension in human cognition. Our minds are capable of both rapid, intuitive leaps and slow, deliberate analysis. While both have their place, it is crucial to recognize the limitations of quick thinking when it comes to matters of importance or complexity.

In our modern world, where information is abundant and easily accessible, the ability to distinguish between ideas accurately has become more critical than ever. We are bombarded with opinions, facts, and pseudo-facts from various sources, making it increasingly challenging to separate truth from falsehood, substance from superficiality.

To cultivate clear judgment and deep reasoning, we must train ourselves to look beyond the immediate appeal of clever associations. We must develop the discipline to engage in careful analysis, to question our assumptions, and to seek out diverse perspectives. Only through this deliberate and often challenging process can we hope to achieve a true understanding of the world around us and make informed decisions based on well-reasoned judgments.. Passage two: How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.. Passage one: TAMBURLAINE. Now clear the triple region of the air,
And let the Majesty of Heaven behold
Their scourge and terror tread on emperors.
Smile, stars that reign'd at my nativity,
And dim the brightness of your neighbour lamps;
Disdain to borrow light of Cynthia!
For I, the chiefest lamp of all the earth,
First rising in the east with mild aspect,
But fixed now in the meridian line,
Will send up fire to your turning spheres,
And cause the sun to borrow light of you.
My sword struck fire from his coat of steel,
Even in Bithynia, when I took this Turk;
As when a fiery exhalation,
Wrapt in the bowels of a freezing cloud,
Fighting for passage, make[s] the welkin crack,
And casts a flash of lightning to the earth:
But, ere I march to wealthy Persia,
Or leave Damascus and th' Egyptian fields,
As was the fame of Clymene's brain-sick son
That almost brent the axle-tree of heaven,
So shall our swords, our lances, and our shot
Fill all the air with fiery meteors;
Then, when the sky shall wax as red as blood,
It shall be said I made it red myself,
To make me think of naught but blood and war.
ZABINA. Unworthy king, that by thy cruelty
Unlawfully usurp'st the Persian seat,
Dar'st thou, that never saw an emperor
Before thou met my husband in the field,
Being thy captive, thus abuse his state,
Keeping his kingly body in a cage,
That roofs of gold and sun-bright palaces
Should have prepar'd to entertain his grace?
And treading him beneath thy loathsome feet,
Whose feet the kings of Africa have kiss'd?. Passage two: Tamburlaine stood before his court, his eyes gleaming with pride and ambition. "Behold," he proclaimed, "the might of Tamburlaine! I am the brightest star in the firmament of power, outshining all emperors and kings. Even the celestial bodies bend to my will, for I am the master of all I survey."

He paced the opulent hall, recounting his latest triumph. "In Bithynia, my armies swept across the land like a tempest, leaving nothing but conquest in their wake. And now, we turn our gaze to Persia and beyond. My forces will descend upon them like locusts, devouring all in their path. No city will stand, no army will prevail against us."

As Tamburlaine's boasts echoed through the chamber, Zabina, her face etched with disdain, stepped forward. "You speak of power and glory," she spat, "but your words are as hollow as your claim to the Persian throne. You are nothing but a usurper, a cruel tyrant who has stolen what is not rightfully his."

Her eyes flashed with anger as she continued, "My husband, the true emperor, once commanded the respect and admiration of nations. Now you keep him captive, stripped of his dignity. Your actions are an affront to all that is just and honorable in this world."

Tamburlaine's expression darkened at Zabina's words, but she stood her ground, unflinching. "You may boast of your conquests and your control over the heavens," she concluded, "but history will remember you as nothing more than a brutal despot, whose reign was built on the suffering of others.". Passage one: In the annals of Danish history, a tale of conquest and its consequences unfolds. The previous monarch of Denmark, driven by ambition and pride, engaged in a fierce battle with King Fortinbras of Norway. In a decisive victory, the Danish king slew his Norwegian counterpart, and through a subsequent treaty, claimed vast swathes of Norwegian territory as spoils of war.

Now, years later, the young Prince Fortinbras, son of the fallen Norwegian king, seeks to reclaim his father's lost lands. Burning with a desire for vengeance and restoration, he has rallied a band of fierce warriors, many of whom are outlaws and mercenaries with little to lose. These men, hardened by life on the fringes of society, are eager for the promise of glory and riches that Fortinbras offers.

The young prince's actions have not gone unnoticed. Word of his plans has reached the Danish court, sending ripples of concern through the kingdom. In response, Denmark has begun to mobilize its forces, shoring up defenses and increasing patrols along its borders. The air is thick with tension as the nation prepares for a potential invasion.

This looming threat explains the flurry of military activity visible throughout Denmark. From coastal watchtowers to inland fortresses, soldiers stand at the ready, their vigilance a testament to the gravity of the situation. Whose image even but now appear’d to us,
Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
Thereto prick’d on by a most emulate pride,
Dar’d to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet,
For so this side of our known world esteem’d him,
Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal’d compact,
Well ratified by law and heraldry,
Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
Which he stood seiz’d of, to the conqueror;
Against the which, a moiety competent
Was gaged by our King; which had return’d
To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he been vanquisher; as by the same cov’nant
And carriage of the article design’d,
His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
Of unimproved mettle, hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
Shark’d up a list of lawless resolutes,
For food and diet, to some enterprise
That hath a stomach in’t; which is no other,
As it doth well appear unto our state,
But to recover of us by strong hand
And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
So by his father lost. And this, I take it,
Is the main motive of our preparations,
The source of this our watch, and the chief head
Of this post-haste and rummage in the land.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: In the depths of the moonlit forest, Demetrius pressed on, his eyes scanning the shadowy undergrowth for any sign of Lysander and Hermia. His determined stride was matched only by Helena's unwavering pursuit, her heart aflutter with desperate longing.

"Demetrius, wait!" Helena called out, her voice tinged with both hope and desperation. "Why do you run from me? Can you not see how much I adore you?"

Demetrius whirled around, his face a mask of irritation. "Helena, I've told you a thousand times – leave me be! I do not love you, nor will I ever. Your persistence only serves to vex me further."

Undeterred by his harsh words, Helena stepped closer, her eyes shimmering with unshed tears. "I know you speak cruelly, but even your disdain is precious to me. Treat me as your spaniel, I beg you. Spurn me, strike me, neglect me – I will follow still, unworthy as I am."

Demetrius's expression softened for a moment, touched by her devotion, before hardening once more. "Do not tempt the contempt of my spirit, for I am sick when I look on thee."

"And I am sick when I look not on you," Helena replied, her voice barely above a whisper.

With a frustrated growl, Demetrius turned and plunged back into the forest, leaving Helena to trail behind, her love burning as brightly as ever despite the cold reception it received.. Passage two: DEMETRIUS.
I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.
Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?
The one I’ll slay, the other slayeth me.
Thou told’st me they were stol’n into this wood,
And here am I, and wode within this wood
Because I cannot meet with Hermia.
Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
HELENA.
You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant,
But yet you draw not iron, for my heart
Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,
And I shall have no power to follow you.
DEMETRIUS.
Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?
Or rather do I not in plainest truth
Tell you I do not, nor I cannot love you?
HELENA.
And even for that do I love you the more.
I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,
The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,
Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,
Unworthy as I am, to follow you.
What worser place can I beg in your love,
(And yet a place of high respect with me)
Than to be usèd as you use your dog?
DEMETRIUS.
Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;
For I am sick when I do look on thee.
HELENA.
And I am sick when I look not on you.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: Macbeth stood in the dimly lit chamber, his eyes fixed on the two men before him. These were no ordinary men, but killers he had summoned for a dark purpose. With calculated words, he began to speak, his voice low and persuasive.

"Gentlemen," he said, "I trust you haven't forgotten the injustices Banquo inflicted upon you. How he crushed your spirits and robbed you of opportunities. The wounds he caused must still be fresh in your minds."

The murderers shifted uneasily, their faces etched with lingering resentment. Macbeth pressed on, his words carefully chosen to stoke their anger.

"Tell me," he continued, "are you so meek, so Christian-like, that you'd let these offenses go unpunished? Are you men of such patience that you'd turn the other cheek to one who's wronged you so grievously?"

He paused, allowing his words to sink in, watching as their expressions hardened with rekindled fury. Then, he delivered his masterstroke.

"I have a proposition for you," Macbeth said, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "A chance to right these wrongs and elevate yourselves in the process. Banquo's continued existence is a thorn in my side, and by extension, an obstacle to your own advancement."

The murderers leaned in, their interest piqued. Macbeth smiled inwardly, knowing he had them in his grasp.

"Remove this obstacle," he urged, "and you'll not only have your revenge but also my eternal gratitude. Think of the possibilities that would open up for men in my favor. Are you not men enough to seize this opportunity?"

He watched as determination replaced hesitation in their eyes. With a few well-chosen words, Macbeth had transformed their grudge into a deadly purpose, manipulating them to serve his own sinister ends. The trap was set, and Banquo's fate was sealed.. Passage two: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
FIRST MURDERER.
It was, so please your Highness.
MACBETH.
Well then, now
Have you consider’d of my speeches? Know
That it was he, in the times past, which held you
So under fortune, which you thought had been
Our innocent self? This I made good to you
In our last conference, pass’d in probation with you
How you were borne in hand, how cross’d, the instruments,
Who wrought with them, and all things else that might
To half a soul and to a notion craz’d
Say, “Thus did Banquo.”
FIRST MURDERER.
You made it known to us.
MACBETH.
I did so; and went further, which is now
Our point of second meeting. Do you find
Your patience so predominant in your nature,
That you can let this go? Are you so gospell’d,
To pray for this good man and for his issue,
Whose heavy hand hath bow’d you to the grave,
And beggar’d yours forever?
FIRST MURDERER.
We are men, my liege.
MACBETH.
Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men;
As hounds, and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,
Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept
All by the name of dogs: the valu’d file
Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,
The housekeeper, the hunter, every one
According to the gift which bounteous nature
Hath in him clos’d; whereby he does receive
Particular addition, from the bill
That writes them all alike: and so of men.
Now, if you have a station in the file,
Not i’ th’ worst rank of manhood, say’t;
And I will put that business in your bosoms,
Whose execution takes your enemy off,
Grapples you to the heart and love of us,
Who wear our health but sickly in his life,
Which in his death were perfect.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: Oft, when the world imagine women stray,
The Sylphs thro' mystic mazes guide their way,
Thro' all the giddy circle they pursue,
And old impertinence expel by new.
What tender maid but must a victim fall
To one man's treat, but for another's ball?
When Florio speaks what virgin could withstand,
If gentle Damon did not squeeze her hand?
With varying vanities, from ev'ry part,
They shift the moving Toyshop of their heart;
Where wigs with wigs, with sword-knots sword-knots strive,
Beaux banish beaux, and coaches coaches drive.
This erring mortals Levity may call;
Oh blind to truth! the Sylphs contrive it all.
Of these am I, who thy protection claim,
A watchful sprite, and Ariel is my name.
Late, as I rang'd the crystal wilds of air,
In the clear Mirror of thy ruling Star
I saw, alas! some dread event impend,
Ere to the main this morning sun descend,
But heav'n reveals not what, or how, or where:
Warn'd by the Sylph, oh pious maid, beware!
This to disclose is all thy guardian can:
Beware of all, but most beware of Man!"
He said; when Shock, who thought she slept too long,
Leap'd up, and wak'd his mistress with his tongue.
'T was then, Belinda, if report say true,
Thy eyes first open'd on a Billet-doux;
Wounds, Charms, and Ardors were no sooner read,
But all the Vision vanish'd from thy head.. Passage two: In the ethereal realm of the Sylphs, these mystical spirits play a crucial role in guiding the actions of mortal women. Passage one: In the verdant depths of an ancient forest, there lived a Nymph of unparalleled beauty. Her presence was a sight to behold, captivating all who crossed her path with her radiant appearance and vivacious spirit. Upon her chest, she wore a dazzling cross that gleamed in the dappled sunlight, drawing admiration and reverence from those who gazed upon it.

The Nymph's allure was so potent that men found themselves helplessly drawn to her, their hearts and minds ensnared by her charms. Even her flaws, if any existed, seemed to vanish in the presence of her enchanting visage. Her beauty was not merely skin deep; it emanated from within, casting a spell on all who encountered her.

Perhaps her most striking feature was her hair, two graceful locks that cascaded down her back like silken waterfalls. These tresses were more than mere adornments; they were like delicate snares, capable of entwining the hearts of even the mightiest men. Many had fallen under their spell, but none more so than a daring Baron who chanced upon the Nymph one fateful day.

The moment the Baron laid eyes on those bewitching locks, he was consumed by an overwhelming desire to possess them. His infatuation knew no bounds, and he resolved to obtain these treasured tresses by any means necessary. Whether through force or guile, he was determined to claim this prize, heedless of the consequences that might befall him in his pursuit of such ethereal beauty.

As the Baron plotted his course of action, the forest seemed to hold its breath, awaiting the outcome of this impending clash between mortal desire and immortal grace.. Passage two: Not with more glories, in th' etherial plain,
The Sun first rises o'er the purpled main,
Than, issuing forth, the rival of his beams
Launch'd on the bosom of the silver Thames.
Fair Nymphs, and well-drest Youths around her shone.
But ev'ry eye was fix'd on her alone.
On her white breast a sparkling Cross she wore,
Which Jews might kiss, and Infidels adore.
Her lively looks a sprightly mind disclose,
Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as those:
Favours to none, to all she smiles extends;
Oft she rejects, but never once offends.
Bright as the sun, her eyes the gazers strike,
And, like the sun, they shine on all alike.
Yet graceful ease, and sweetness void of pride,
Might hide her faults, if Belles had faults to hide:
If to her share some female errors fall,
Look on her face, and you'll forget 'em all.
This Nymph, to the destruction of mankind,
Nourish'd two Locks, which graceful hung behind
In equal curls, and well conspir'd to deck
With shining ringlets the smooth iv'ry neck.
Love in these labyrinths his slaves detains,
And mighty hearts are held in slender chains.
With hairy springes we the birds betray,
Slight lines of hair surprise the finny prey,
Fair tresses man's imperial race ensnare,
And beauty draws us with a single hair.
Th' advent'rous Baron the bright locks admir'd;
He saw, he wish'd, and to the prize aspir'd.
Resolv'd to win, he meditates the way,
By force to ravish, or by fraud betray;
For when success a Lover's toil attends,
Few ask, if fraud or force attain'd his ends.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: 且夫天下非小弱也，雍州之地，崤函之固，自若也。陈涉之位，非尊于齐、楚、燕、赵、韩、魏、宋、卫、中山之君也；锄櫌棘矜，非铦于钩戟长铩也；谪戍之众，非抗于九国之师也；深谋远虑，行军用兵之道，非及乡时之士也。然而成败异变，功业相反，何也？试使山东之国与陈涉度长絜大，比权量力，则不可同年而语矣。然秦以区区之地，致万乘之势，序八州而朝同列，百有余年矣；然后以六合为家，崤函为宫；一夫作难而七庙隳，身死人手，为天下笑者，何也？仁义不施而攻守之势异也。. Passage one: 行略定秦地。函谷关有兵守关，不得入。又闻沛公已破咸阳，项羽大怒，使当阳君等击关。项羽遂入，至于戏西。沛公军霸上，未得与项羽相见。沛公左司马曹无伤，使人言于项羽曰：“沛公欲王关中，使子婴为相，珍宝尽有之。”项羽大怒曰：“旦日飨士卒，为击破沛公军！”当是时，项羽兵四十万，在新丰鸿门；沛公兵十万，在霸上。范增说项羽曰：“沛公居山东时，贪于财货，好美姬。今入关，财物无所取，妇女无所幸，此其志不在小。吾令人望其气，皆为龙虎，成五采，此天子气也。急击勿失！”. Passage two: 项羽闻沛公破咸阳，欲王关中，大怒曰："此乃背信弃义之举也！"遂召诸将议攻之策。范增进言曰："沛公志不在小，其心必图天下。今不速击，恐失良机。"项羽颔首，曰："然。"乃命诸将整军备战。

是夜，项羽辗转难眠，思及与沛公昔日之交，不禁叹曰："奈何今日兵戎相见乎？"翌日，项羽登高望远，见沛公军势浩大，心中不免生疑。范增察其色，进曰："王勿忧，我军士气如虹，必能一战而胜。"项羽闻言，顿觉豪情万丈，遂下令进军，誓破沛公。. You have been shown two different passages. Passage two: 呜呼！吾少孤，及长，不省所怙，惟兄嫂是依。中年兄殁南方，吾与汝俱幼，从嫂归葬河阳。既又与汝就食江南，零丁孤苦，未尝一日相离也。吾上有三兄，皆不幸早世。承先人后者，在孙惟汝，在子惟吾。两世一身，形单影只。嫂尝抚汝指吾而言曰：“韩氏两世，惟此而已！”汝时尤小，当不复记忆；吾时虽能记忆，亦未知其言之悲也。. Passage two: 天地人和，各有其道。天有四时，地有五行，人有五常。顺天者昌，逆天者亡。家和万事兴，国泰民安康。上下和睦，长幼有序，君臣相得，朋友相亲。敬天法地，修身齐家，治国平天下。春生夏长，秋收冬藏，此乃自然之理。仁义礼智信，乃人伦之道。时势如水，有涨有落；贫富如轮，有转有移。处顺境而不骄，遇逆境而不惧。知天命，顺人事，方能安身立命，享太平。. Passage one: 柏子潭者，深谷之底也。潭水幽黑，深不可测。有五龙祠焉，相传帝王祈雨于此。潭侧双燕、南白鸽二洞，奇石嶙峋。西去不远，清泉涓涓，名曰让泉。泉旁废亭一座，匾曰"渐入佳境"。淳熙年间，张商卿等地方官吏，曾游览于此，题诗壁间。余至此处，见山水之胜，不禁慨叹造化之工。潭水如镜，倒映青山，洞穴幽深，若隐若现。让泉清冽，流水潺潺，废亭荒芜，更添几分凄凉之美。古人吟咏之处，今犹可想见当年风流。. Passage two: 东南有柏子潭。潭在深谷底，延袤亩余，色正深黑。即欧阳公赛龙处，上有五龙祠。皇上初龙飞，屯兵于滁，会旱暵，亲挟雕弓，注矢于潭者三，约三日雨，如期果大雨。及御宝历，为作栏楯护潭，且新其庙。庙侧有时若亭。濂坐亭上，问潭侧双燕洞及其南白鸽洞，以肆穷览，人无知者，乃止。复西行约三里许，有泉泻出于两山之间，分流而下，曰让泉，潺潺清澈，可鉴毛发。傍岸有亭曰“渐入佳境”，今已废，惟四大字勒崖石间。淳熙中郡守张商卿等题名尚存。. Passage one: 太元之岁，武陵有渔者，缘溪而下，不知行几里。忽逢桃花林夹岸，芳香袭人，落英缤纷。渔人甚异之，复前行，欲穷其林。

林尽水源，便得一山。山有小口，仿佛若有光。便舍船，从口入。初极狭，才通人。复行数十步，豁然开朗。土地平旷，屋舍俨然，有良田美池桑竹之属。阡陌交通，鸡犬相闻。其中往来种作，男女衣着，悉如外人。黄发垂髫，并怡然自乐。

见渔人，乃大惊，问所从来。具答之。便要还家，设酒杀鸡作食。村中闻有此人，咸来问讯。自云先世避秦时乱，率妻子邑人来此绝境，不复出焉，遂与外人间隔。问今是何世，乃不知有汉，无论魏晋。

渔人诧异，欲归告世人。太守遣人随往，寻向所志，遂迷不复得路。南阳刘子骥高尚士也，闻之，欣然规往，未果，寻病终。后遂无问津者。. Passage one: 环滁皆山也。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行六七里，渐闻水声潺潺，而泻出于两峰之间者，酿泉也。峰回路转，有亭翼然临于泉上者，醉翁亭也。作亭者谁？山之僧智仙也。名之者谁？太守自谓也。太守与客来饮于此，饮少辄醉，而年又最高，故自号曰醉翁也。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。若夫日出而林霏开，云归而岩穴暝，晦明变化者，山间之朝暮也。野芳发而幽香，佳木秀而繁阴，风霜高洁，水落而石出者，山间之四时也。朝而往，暮而归，四时之景不同，而乐亦无穷也。至于负者歌于途，行者休于树，前者呼，后者应，伛偻提携，往来而不绝者，滁人游也。临溪而渔，溪深而鱼肥，酿泉为酒，泉香而酒洌，山肴野蔌，杂然而前陈者，太守宴也。宴酣之乐，非丝非竹，射者中，弈者胜，觥筹交错，起坐而喧哗者，众宾欢也。苍颜白发，颓然乎其间者，太守醉也。已而夕阳在山，人影散乱，太守归而宾客从也。树林阴翳，鸣声上下，游人去而禽鸟乐也。然而禽鸟知山林之乐，而不知人之乐；人知从太守游而乐，而不知太守之乐其乐也。醉能同其乐，醒能述以文者，太守也。太守谓谁？庐陵欧阳修也。. Passage two: 滁州西南有琅琊山焉，山不甚高，而秀丽绝伦。山腰有亭，名曰醉翁亭。亭四面环山，林木葱郁，泉水潺潺。春日，百花争艳，莺啼燕语；夏时，绿荫如盖，蝉鸣不绝；秋季，红叶满山，果实累累；冬日，白雪皑皑，松柏常青。

余为太守，常与宾客登此亭，览山水之胜。或携琴抚弄，或吟诗作赋，或对弈饮酒，不觉日暮。山中人亦时来此，或采药，或砍柴，或牧羊，与我等相遇，皆欢然交谈，不分贵贱。

每至佳节，余必邀宾客至此，置酒高会。酒酣耳热之际，或起舞，或高歌，兴致盎然。醉后卧于亭中，闻泉声如佳人之语，闻松涛如大珠小珠落玉盘，不觉心旷神怡，物我两忘。

此亭之乐，不在酒，不在景，而在于人。山水之美，能使人忘却尘世烦恼，返璞归真。人与自然和谐相处，方能体会生命之真谛。余常思：人生苦短，当及时行乐，然乐非独乐，与人同乐，方为至乐。此亭之名，正寓此意也。. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage two: 环滁皆山也。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行六七里，渐闻水声潺潺，而泻出于两峰之间者，酿泉也。峰回路转，有亭翼然临于泉上者，醉翁亭也。作亭者谁？山之僧智仙也。名之者谁？太守自谓也。太守与客来饮于此，饮少辄醉，而年又最高，故自号曰醉翁也。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。若夫日出而林霏开，云归而岩穴暝，晦明变化者，山间之朝暮也。野芳发而幽香，佳木秀而繁阴，风霜高洁，水落而石出者，山间之四时也。朝而往，暮而归，四时之景不同，而乐亦无穷也。至于负者歌于途，行者休于树，前者呼，后者应，伛偻提携，往来而不绝者，滁人游也。临溪而渔，溪深而鱼肥，酿泉为酒，泉香而酒洌，山肴野蔌，杂然而前陈者，太守宴也。宴酣之乐，非丝非竹，射者中，弈者胜，觥筹交错，起坐而喧哗者，众宾欢也。苍颜白发，颓然乎其间者，太守醉也。已而夕阳在山，人影散乱，太守归而宾客从也。树林阴翳，鸣声上下，游人去而禽鸟乐也。然而禽鸟知山林之乐，而不知人之乐；人知从太守游而乐，而不知太守之乐其乐也。醉能同其乐，醒能述以文者，太守也。太守谓谁？庐陵欧阳修也。. Passage one: 有佳人兮，绝世而独立。姿态轻盈若鸿鹤，婀娜多姿如游龙。肌肤胜雪，面若桃花。眉如远山含黛，目似秋水流波。唇若朱丹，齿如齐贝。发若青丝，垂云髻高绾。

其服饰也，华美无双。罗衣曳地，锦绣生辉。珠翠环佩，玉佩叮咚。步履轻盈，举止优雅。回眸一笑，顾盼生辉。

观其容貌，倾国倾城。品其气质，出尘脱俗。端庄高雅，不可方物。世间罕见如此佳人，堪称绝代风华。

若得一见，心醉神迷。若得相伴，此生足矣。美人如斯，天下无双。. Passage two: 余告之曰：其形也，翩若惊鸿，婉若游龙。荣曜秋菊，华茂春松。髣髴兮若轻云之蔽月，飘飖兮若流风之回雪。远而望之，皎若太阳升朝霞；迫而察之，灼若芙蕖出渌波。穠纤得衷，修短合度。肩若削成，腰如约素。延颈秀项，皓质呈露。芳泽无加，铅华弗御。云髻峨峨，修眉联娟。丹唇外朗，皓齿内鲜。明眸善睐，靥辅承权。瓌姿艳逸，仪静体闲。柔情绰态，媚于语言。奇服旷世，骨像应图。披罗衣之璀粲兮，珥瑶碧之华琚。戴金翠之首饰，缀明珠以耀躯。践远游之文履，曳雾绡之轻裾。微幽兰之芳蔼兮，步踟蹰于山隅。于是忽焉纵体，以遨以嬉。左倚采旄，右荫桂旗。攘皓腕于神浒兮，采湍濑之玄芝。. Passage one: 天地有正气，杂然赋流形。下则为河岳，上则为日星。于人曰浩然，沛乎塞苍冥。皇路当清夷，含和吐明庭。时穷节乃见，一一垂丹青。在齐太史简，在晋董狐笔。在秦张良椎，在汉苏武节。为严将军头，为嵇侍中血。为张睢阳齿，为颜常山舌。或为辽东帽，清操厉冰雪。或为出师表，鬼神泣壮烈。或为渡江楫，慷慨吞胡羯。或为击贼笏，逆竖头破裂。是气所磅礴，凛烈万古存。当其贯日月，生死安足论。地维赖以立，天柱赖以尊。三纲实系命，道义为之根。嗟予遘阳九，隶也实不力。楚囚缨其冠，传车送穷北。鼎镬甘如饴，求之不可得。阴房阗鬼火，春院閟天黑。(阗 一作：阒)牛骥同一皂，鸡栖凤凰食。一朝蒙雾露，分作沟中瘠。如此再寒暑，百沴自辟易。嗟哉沮洳场，为我安乐国。岂有他缪巧，阴阳不能贼。顾此耿耿在，仰视浮云白。悠悠我心悲，苍天曷有极。哲人日已远，典刑在夙昔。风檐展书读，古道照颜色。. Passage two: 天地之间，正气浩然。其形虽异，其本则一。盖天地之正气，或见于日月之光，或显于山川之势，或化为风雨雷电，无所不在，无时不有。

Passage one: 张良见樊哙，急告曰："事急矣！项庄舞剑，意在沛公。"樊哙闻之，慨然曰："吾当入与沛公同生死。"遂强入宴，见项王。

樊哙进言曰："大王，沛公功劳甚伟，何以如此相待？昔日沛公率兵攻城略地，为大王立下汗马功劳。今日大王独享富贵，反而疑忌沛公，此乃不义也。"

项王默然，无言以对。樊哙见状，随张良坐下。

须臾，沛公起身曰："吾欲如厕。"项王许之。沛公出，召樊哙曰："事已危急，当速离此。"

樊哙应之，随沛公而去。项王见沛公久不归，心生疑虑。左右告曰："沛公已去。"项王大惊，欲追之而不得。

沛公与樊哙、张良等人匆匆离去，项王悔之晚矣。此后，沛公与项王势同水火，终成楚汉相争之局。. Passage two: 于是张良至军门见樊哙。樊哙曰：“今日之事何如？”良曰：“甚急！今者项庄拔剑舞，其意常在沛公也。”哙曰：“此迫矣！臣请入，与之同命。”哙即带剑拥盾入军门。交戟之卫士欲止不内，樊哙侧其盾以撞，卫士仆地，哙遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目视项王，头发上指，目眦尽裂。项王按剑而跽曰：“客何为者？”张良曰：“沛公之参乘樊哙者也。”项王曰：“壮士！赐之卮酒。”则与斗卮酒。哙拜谢，起，立而饮之。项王曰：“赐之彘肩。”则与一生彘肩。樊哙覆其盾于地，加彘肩上，拔剑切而啖之。项王曰：“壮士！能复饮乎？”樊哙曰：“臣死且不避，卮酒安足辞！夫秦王有虎狼之心，杀人如不能举，刑人如恐不胜，天下皆叛之。怀王与诸将约曰：‘先破秦入咸阳者王之。’今沛公先破秦入咸阳，毫毛不敢有所近，封闭宫室，还军霸上，以待大王来。故遣将守关者，备他盗出入与非常也。劳苦而功高如此，未有封侯之赏，而听细说，欲诛有功之人，此亡秦之续耳。窃为大王不取也！”项王未有以应，曰：“坐。”樊哙从良坐。坐须臾，沛公起如厕，因招樊哙出。. 岁月如梭，女子备受煎熬。终日以泪洗面，形容枯槁。一日，实在难以忍受，向夫君提出归家之请。府吏闻言大惊，急问缘由。女子泣诉婆母之苛刻，府吏心中不忍，却又无可奈何。

女子闻此，心如刀割。往昔岁月，历历在目。初嫁之喜悦，相濡以沫之情深，皆成过眼云烟。今日离去，前路茫茫，不知何往。

收拾行囊之际，女子泪如雨下。回首往事，悔不该轻易许下终身。叹息命运无常，人生难料。府吏欲留，却无计可施。二人依依惜别，互诉衷肠。

Passage two: “十三能织素，十四学裁衣。十五弹箜篌，十六诵诗书。十七为君妇，心中常苦悲。君既为府吏，守节情不移。贱妾留空房，相见常日稀。鸡鸣入机织，夜夜不得息。三日断五匹，大人故嫌迟。非为织作迟，君家妇难为！妾不堪驱使，徒留无所施。便可白公姥，及时相遣归。” 府吏得闻之，堂上启阿母：“儿已薄禄相，幸复得此妇。结发同枕席，黄泉共为友。共事二三年，始尔未为久。女行无偏斜，何意致不厚。” 阿母谓府吏：“何乃太区区！此妇无礼节，举动自专由。吾意久怀忿，汝岂得自由！东家有贤女，自名秦罗敷。可怜体无比，阿母为汝求。便可速遣之，遣去慎莫留！” 府吏长跪告：“伏惟启阿母。今若遣此妇，终老不复取！” 阿母得闻之，槌床便大怒：“小子无所畏，何敢助妇语！吾已失恩义，会不相从许！” 府吏默无声，再拜还入户。举言谓新妇，哽咽不能语：“我自不驱卿，逼迫有阿母。卿但暂还家，吾今且报府。不久当归还，还必相迎取。以此下心意，慎勿违吾语。” 新妇谓府吏：“勿复重纷纭。往昔初阳岁，谢家来贵门。奉事循公姥，进止敢自专？昼夜勤作息，伶俜萦苦辛。谓言无罪过，供养卒大恩；仍更被驱遣，何言复来还！妾有绣腰襦，葳蕤自生光；红罗复斗帐，四角垂香囊；箱帘六七十，绿碧青丝绳，物物各自异，种种在其中。人贱物亦鄙，不足迎后人，留待作遗施，于今无会因。时时为安慰，久久莫相忘！”. Passage one: 余以乾隆三十九年十二月，自京师乘风雪，历齐河、长清，穿泰山西北谷，越长城之限，至于泰安。是月丁未，与知府朱孝纯子颍由南麓登。四十五里，道皆砌石为磴，其级七千有余。泰山正南面有三谷。中谷绕泰安城下，郦道元所谓环水也。余始循以入，道少半，越中岭，复循西谷，遂至其巅。古时登山，循东谷入，道有天门。东谷者，古谓之天门溪水，余所不至也。今所经中岭及山巅，崖限当道者，世皆谓之天门云。道中迷雾冰滑，磴几不可登。及既上，苍山负雪，明烛天南。望晚日照城郭，汶水、徂徕如画，而半山居雾若带然。 戊申晦，五鼓，与子颍坐日观亭，待日出。大风扬积雪击面。亭东自足下皆云漫。稍见云中白若樗蒱数十立者，山也。极天云一线异色，须臾成五采。日上，正赤如丹，下有红光动摇承之。或曰，此东海也。回视日观以西峰，或得日或否，绛皓驳色，而皆若偻。 亭西有岱祠，又有碧霞元君祠。皇帝行宫在碧霞元君祠东。是日观道中石刻，自唐显庆以来；其远古刻尽漫失。僻不当道者，皆不及往。 山多石，少土。石苍黑色，多平方，少圜。少杂树，多松，生石罅，皆平顶。冰雪，无瀑水，无鸟兽音迹。至日观数里内无树，而雪与人膝齐。 桐城姚鼐记。. 初至山麓，见石阶蜿蜒，直通云霄。攀援而上，步步艰辛。山路崎岖，时有巨石横亘，险峻处需手足并用。途中遇石亭小憩，俯瞰山下，云雾缭绕，恍若仙境。

继续前行，树木渐稀，寒风凛冽。冰雪覆盖山顶，步履维艰。终至巅峰，喜不自胜。夜宿山巅，翌日观日出。

晨曦初露，霞光万丈，红日徐徐升起，光芒四射，照耀群山。此景壮美，令人叹为观止。

I would not be the villain that thou think’st
For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp
And the rich East to boot.
MALCOLM.

I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
I think our country sinks beneath the yoke;

Of goodly thousands: but, for all this,

Hero and Ursula were dishing about Beatrice and Benedick's relationship. Ursula wondered if Benedick genuinely loved Beatrice, and Hero confirmed it, citing the Prince and her fiancé's opinions. It seemed Hero was trying to protect Benedick from Beatrice's sharp tongue, but Ursula thought he was up to the challenge and that Beatrice would be the perfect match for him.. Passage two: No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
URSULA.
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
HERO.
So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord.
URSULA.
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
HERO.
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
URSULA.
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
HERO.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?
