Passage one: Pandarus has other intentions; and, while Troilus writes daily letters with increasing love, he contrives the means of an interview. Seeking out Deiphobus, the brother of Troilus, he tells him that Cressida is in danger of violence from Polyphete, and asks protection for her. Deiphobus gladly complies, promises the protection of Hector and Helen, and goes to invite Cressida to dinner on the morrow. Meantime Pandarus instructs Troilus to go to the house of Deiphobus, plead an access of his fever for remaining all night, and keep his chamber next day. “Lo,” says the crafty promoter of love, borrowing a phrase from the hunting-field; “Lo, hold thee at thy tristre close, and I shall well the deer unto thy bowe drive.” Unsuspicious of stratagem, Cressida comes to dinner; and at table, Helen, Pandarus, and others, praise the absent Troilus, until “her heart laughs” for very pride that she has the love of such a knight. After dinner they speak of Cressida’s business; all confirm Deiphobus’ assurances of protection and aid; and Pandarus suggests that, since Troilus is there, Cressida shall herself tell him her case. Helen and Deiphobus alone accompany Pandarus to Troilus’ chamber; there Troilus produces some documents relating to the public weal, which Hector has sent for his opinion; Helen and Deiphobus, engrossed in perusal and discussion, roam out of the chamber, by a stair, into the garden; while Pandarus goes down to the hall, and, pretending that his brother and Helen are still with Troilus, brings Cressida to her lover. The Second Book leaves Pandarus whispering in his niece’s ear counsel to be merciful and kind to her lover, that hath for her such pain; while Troilus lies “in a kankerdort,” hearing the whispering without, and wondering what he shall say for this “was the first time that he should her pray of love; O! mighty God! what shall he say?”. Passage two: Pandarus, his heart set on uniting Troilus and the fair Cressida, sought out Deiphobus, brother to the lovesick youth. With cunning words, he wove a tale of Cressida's vulnerability, suggesting that the noble Polyphete posed a threat from which she needed safeguarding. Deiphobus, ever honorable, readily agreed to shield the lady, proposing a dinner at his own residence. To ensure the plan's success, Hector, mightiest of warriors, and Helen, fairest of women, pledged their support.

Meanwhile, Pandarus, a master of intrigue, instructed Troilus to feign illness and take to his bed at Deiphobus' house. As evening descended and the guests assembled, Helen and Pandarus, their words carefully chosen, began to extol Troilus' virtues – his bravery in battle, his nobility of spirit, and the depth of his unspoken love for Cressida. These praises, falling upon Cressida's ears, filled her with a secret pride, kindling a spark of affection within her heart.

The hour was ripe, Pandarus decided. Leaning towards Cressida, he suggested that she confide her troubles directly to Troilus, a man known for his discretion and sound counsel.  With subtle maneuvering, he then contrived to distract both Helen and Deiphobus, engaging them in the perusal of weighty documents.  Thus, with the path cleared, he led Cressida, her heart aflutter with a mixture of apprehension and anticipation, to the chamber where Troilus lay, his heart pounding in his chest, desperately rehearsing the words with which he longed to declare his ardent love for the first time.

Passage one: At least, the whisper goes so. Our last King,
Whose image even but now appear’d to us,
Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
Thereto prick’d on by a most emulate pride,
Dar’d to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet,
For so this side of our known world esteem’d him,
Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal’d compact,
Well ratified by law and heraldry,
Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
Which he stood seiz’d of, to the conqueror;
Against the which, a moiety competent
Was gaged by our King; which had return’d
To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he been vanquisher; as by the same cov’nant
And carriage of the article design’d,
His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
Of unimproved mettle, hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
Shark’d up a list of lawless resolutes,
For food and diet, to some enterprise
That hath a stomach in’t; which is no other,
As it doth well appear unto our state,
But to recover of us by strong hand
And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
So by his father lost. And this, I take it,
Is the main motive of our preparations,
The source of this our watch, and the chief head
Of this post-haste and rummage in the land.. Passage two: Lo, listen closely, for I shall tell a tale of ancient strife, of kings and conquest, and a son's burning vengeance. In days of yore, upon the frozen fields of Denmark, a fearsome battle raged, where the Danish King, consumed by pride's dark fire, clashed with Fortinbras, the Norwegian King. Steel met steel, a symphony of war, and when the dust settled, Fortinbras lay lifeless, his crown forfeit.

A treaty, etched in blood and victory, granted the Danish King dominion over Fortinbras's lands, a prize of conquest. Yet, from the ashes of defeat rose young Fortinbras, his heart aflame with the need for retribution. He rallied to his side a band of hardened warriors, men who lived on the edge of law, their swords thirsty for battle. They sought not gold nor glory, but the restoration of what was lost, the reclaiming of their stolen birthright.

Thus, a shadow of war falls upon Denmark, a specter of the past returned to haunt the present. The drums of conflict beat anew, calling the kingdom to arms, their vigilance fueled by the ever-present threat of young Fortinbras and his restless, vengeful host. For they know, as winter's icy grip tightens upon the land, so too does the resolve of their enemies, and the echoes of their fallen king's name spur them towards an uncertain, and possibly bloody, dawn.

Passage one: Demetrius, weary from his pursuit of the fleeing lovers, stumbled through the moon-dappled woods. The night air, thick with the scent of pine and damp earth, echoed with the insistent calls of Helena, her voice a persistent chirp against the low hum of the forest.  

"Demetrius!" she cried, her voice breathless with exertion. "Wait for me! Why do you run so swiftly from the one who loves you most?"

He stopped, his tall form a silhouette against the silvered leaves.  Turning to face her, his voice was sharp with annoyance. "I have told you, woman, my heart belongs elsewhere. Your affections are wasted on me, like seeds scattered on barren ground."

Helena, undeterred, merely drew closer, her eyes shining with a love that bordered on madness. "Call me your dog, then," she whispered, her voice trembling with a desperate need. "I will follow at your heel, content with the merest crumb of your regard.  Kick me, despise me, but allow me to remain by your side."

Demetrius, exasperated by her relentless pursuit, turned from her with a muttered curse, his heart unmoved by her pleas. He plunged deeper into the shadowed woods, leaving Helena standing alone, a solitary figure amidst the ancient trees, her heart stubbornly clinging to a love that would never be hers.

Passage one: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
FIRST MURDERER.
It was, so please your Highness.
MACBETH.
Well then, now
Have you consider’d of my speeches? Know
That it was he, in the times past, which held you
So under fortune, which you thought had been
Our innocent self? This I made good to you
In our last conference, pass’d in probation with you
How you were borne in hand, how cross’d, the instruments,
Who wrought with them, and all things else that might
To half a soul and to a notion craz’d
Say, “Thus did Banquo.”
FIRST MURDERER.
You made it known to us.
MACBETH.
I did so; and went further, which is now
Our point of second meeting. Do you find
Your patience so predominant in your nature,
That you can let this go? Are you so gospell’d,
To pray for this good man and for his issue,
Whose heavy hand hath bow’d you to the grave,
And beggar’d yours forever?
FIRST MURDERER.
We are men, my liege.
MACBETH.
Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men;
As hounds, and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,
Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept
All by the name of dogs: the valu’d file
Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,
The housekeeper, the hunter, every one
According to the gift which bounteous nature
Hath in him clos’d; whereby he does receive
Particular addition, from the bill
That writes them all alike: and so of men.
Now, if you have a station in the file,
Not i’ th’ worst rank of manhood, say’t;
And I will put that business in your bosoms,
Whose execution takes your enemy off,
Grapples you to the heart and love of us,
Who wear our health but sickly in his life,
Which in his death were perfect.. Passage two: "Hark, ye men of grim visage! Do you still bear the weight of past grievances, the sting of injustices dealt by the hand of Banquo? Remember his tyranny, the shadow he cast upon your lives, the opportunities stolen, the respect denied. Can such wounds ever truly heal while he yet draws breath? I see the fire of resentment smoldering in your eyes, yet I must question the depths of your resolve.  Do you possess the mettle, the unyielding spirit, to seize this opportunity for righteous vengeance? 

This deed, I say, is not born of malice but of necessity, a purging of a festering wound on the body of fate itself. Strike down Banquo, and you strike down the embodiment of your misfortune. Rise above the shackles of your past, claim dominion over your own destiny.  Prove yourselves as men of action, not of hollow words and empty grievances.  The rewards for such unwavering loyalty, for such decisive action, shall be vast.  Elevation awaits, a chance to stand beside me as we reshape this land, to share in the bounty of a new era. But know this:  hesitation breeds only further suffering. The time for contemplation is over; the time for action is now."

Passage one: The chamber hushed, bathed in the ethereal glow of the setting sun. A delicate figure, Belinda, lay sleeping, her bosom gently rising and falling with each peaceful breath. Around her, unseen by mortal eyes, danced a whirlwind of Sylphs, their gossamer wings shimmering with iridescent light. These were no mere figments of fancy, but powerful spirits, guardians of womanhood, wielding their magic to guide the hearts and minds of women. 

One among them, Ariel, resplendent and grave, hovered above Belinda’s head. A tremor of worry passed through his ethereal form as he observed the sleeping maiden. "Be warned, dear Belinda," he whispered, his voice a symphony of tinkling bells, "for dangers lurk in the shadows, dangers that wear a pleasing guise. Beware the honeyed words, the smoldering glances, the touch that promises more than it can give."

He went on to weave tales of men, their hearts ablaze with fleeting passions, their promises as ephemeral as morning mist. He spoke of women ensnared by sweet deceptions, their own desires twisted into weapons against them. "Remember my words, Belinda," he urged, his voice growing fainter as dawn approached, "for the path of love is fraught with peril."

But alas, his warning was fated to fall on deaf ears. As the first rays of sunlight pierced the darkness, Belinda stirred from her slumber, her dream fading into the tapestry of the coming day. A love letter, adorned with flourishes of passionate ink, lay upon her bedside table, its seductive allure instantly eclipsing the fading whispers of Ariel's caution. With a heart aflutter, she reached for the letter, the Sylph's warning lost in the burgeoning anticipation of a lover's words.

The Sylphs thro' mystic mazes guide their way,
Thro' all the giddy circle they pursue,
And old impertinence expel by new.
What tender maid but must a victim fall
To one man's treat, but for another's ball?
When Florio speaks what virgin could withstand,
If gentle Damon did not squeeze her hand?
With varying vanities, from ev'ry part,
They shift the moving Toyshop of their heart;
Where wigs with wigs, with sword-knots sword-knots strive,
Beaux banish beaux, and coaches coaches drive.
This erring mortals Levity may call;
Oh blind to truth! the Sylphs contrive it all.
Of these am I, who thy protection claim,
A watchful sprite, and Ariel is my name.
Late, as I rang'd the crystal wilds of air,
In the clear Mirror of thy ruling Star
I saw, alas! some dread event impend,
Ere to the main this morning sun descend,
But heav'n reveals not what, or how, or where:
Warn'd by the Sylph, oh pious maid, beware!
This to disclose is all thy guardian can:
Beware of all, but most beware of Man!"
He said; when Shock, who thought she slept too long,
Leap'd up, and wak'd his mistress with his tongue.
'T was then, Belinda, if report say true,
Thy eyes first open'd on a Billet-doux;
Wounds, Charms, and Ardors were no sooner read,

The Sylphs thro' mystic mazes guide their way,
Thro' all the giddy circle they pursue,
And old impertinence expel by new.
What tender maid but must a victim fall
To one man's treat, but for another's ball?
When Florio speaks what virgin could withstand,
If gentle Damon did not squeeze her hand?
With varying vanities, from ev'ry part,
They shift the moving Toyshop of their heart;
Where wigs with wigs, with sword-knots sword-knots strive,
Beaux banish beaux, and coaches coaches drive.
This erring mortals Levity may call;
Oh blind to truth! the Sylphs contrive it all.
Of these am I, who thy protection claim,
A watchful sprite, and Ariel is my name.
Late, as I rang'd the crystal wilds of air,
In the clear Mirror of thy ruling Star
I saw, alas! some dread event impend,
Ere to the main this morning sun descend,
But heav'n reveals not what, or how, or where:
Warn'd by the Sylph, oh pious maid, beware!
This to disclose is all thy guardian can:
Beware of all, but most beware of Man!"
He said; when Shock, who thought she slept too long,
Leap'd up, and wak'd his mistress with his tongue.
'T was then, Belinda, if report say true,
Thy eyes first open'd on a Billet-doux;
Wounds, Charms, and Ardors were no sooner read,
But all the Vision vanish'd from thy head.. Passage two: The chamber hushed, bathed in the ethereal glow of the setting sun. A delicate figure, Belinda, lay sleeping, her bosom gently rising and falling with each peaceful breath. Around her, unseen by mortal eyes, danced a whirlwind of Sylphs, their gossamer wings shimmering with iridescent light. These were no mere figments of fancy, but powerful spirits, guardians of womanhood, wielding their magic to guide the hearts and minds of women. 

One among them, Ariel, resplendent and grave, hovered above Belinda’s head. A tremor of worry passed through his ethereal form as he observed the sleeping maiden. "Be warned, dear Belinda," he whispered, his voice a symphony of tinkling bells, "for dangers lurk in the shadows, dangers that wear a pleasing guise. Beware the honeyed words, the smoldering glances, the touch that promises more than it can give."

He went on to weave tales of men, their hearts ablaze with fleeting passions, their promises as ephemeral as morning mist. He spoke of women ensnared by sweet deceptions, their own desires twisted into weapons against them. "Remember my words, Belinda," he urged, his voice growing fainter as dawn approached, "for the path of love is fraught with peril."

But alas, his warning was fated to fall on deaf ears. As the first rays of sunlight pierced the darkness, Belinda stirred from her slumber, her dream fading into the tapestry of the coming day. A love letter, adorned with flourishes of passionate ink, lay upon her bedside table, its seductive allure instantly eclipsing the fading whispers of Ariel's caution. With a heart aflutter, she reached for the letter, the Sylph's warning lost in the burgeoning anticipation of a lover's words.

Passage one: Not with more glories, in th' etherial plain,
The Sun first rises o'er the purpled main,
Than, issuing forth, the rival of his beams
Launch'd on the bosom of the silver Thames.
Fair Nymphs, and well-drest Youths around her shone.
But ev'ry eye was fix'd on her alone.
On her white breast a sparkling Cross she wore,
Which Jews might kiss, and Infidels adore.
Her lively looks a sprightly mind disclose,
Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as those:
Favours to none, to all she smiles extends;
Oft she rejects, but never once offends.
Bright as the sun, her eyes the gazers strike,
And, like the sun, they shine on all alike.
Yet graceful ease, and sweetness void of pride,
Might hide her faults, if Belles had faults to hide:
If to her share some female errors fall,
Look on her face, and you'll forget 'em all.
This Nymph, to the destruction of mankind,
Nourish'd two Locks, which graceful hung behind
In equal curls, and well conspir'd to deck
With shining ringlets the smooth iv'ry neck.
Love in these labyrinths his slaves detains,
And mighty hearts are held in slender chains.
With hairy springes we the birds betray,
Slight lines of hair surprise the finny prey,
Fair tresses man's imperial race ensnare,
And beauty draws us with a single hair.
Th' advent'rous Baron the bright locks admir'd;
He saw, he wish'd, and to the prize aspir'd.
Resolv'd to win, he meditates the way,
By force to ravish, or by fraud betray;
For when success a Lover's toil attends,
Few ask, if fraud or force attain'd his ends.. Passage two: Behold! There dwelled in a realm veiled in mist and ancient forest, a Nymph of unearthly beauty. Her laughter, like the tinkling of a woodland stream, danced upon the air, and her eyes, shimmering pools reflecting starlight, held captive the very souls of men. Upon her breast, a cross of purest crystal blazed, a beacon of ethereal light that drew forth admiration and whispered prayers in equal measure.

Her allure was a potent enchantment, woven from the whisper of the wind through the trees and the captivating rhythm of her graceful movements.  Men, ensnared by her captivating charm, readily forgave any perceived flaw, their hearts melting like morning frost beneath the radiance of her gaze.  Two silken tresses, spun from moonlight and gossamer dreams, flowed down her back, each a cunning snare for the hearts of even the mightiest warriors.

One day, a bold Baron, hardened by countless battles and renowned for his unwavering resolve, chanced upon this vision of loveliness. The world around him faded, eclipsed by the radiant glow of the Nymph. His gaze, ever seeking conquest, fell upon the two shimmering locks framing her delicate features, and a fierce desire ignited within his soul. He swore a silent oath, vowing to possess those silken strands, to hold a piece of her ethereal beauty, no matter the cost. Whether by honeyed words or the sharp edge of his blade, the Baron would claim his prize, his heart ensnared by the Nymph with the captivating gaze and the alluring, moonlit locks.

Passage one: 夫秦地险固，带河山之险，拥崤函之固，甲兵强盛，可谓雄踞天下。然暴虐无道，不施仁义，视黎民如草芥，驱百姓以赴死，故天下汹汹，怨声载道。  

   陈涉者，一介草莽，出身寒微，  然揭竿而起，应者云集。何也？  盖因其心怀仁义，  体恤百姓疾苦，故能得民心，以弱胜强，终成灭秦之势。  

   由此观之，  仁义者，  国家之根本也。失之，则民心离散，  国势衰微；得之，则民心归附，  天下可定。  秦之兴亡，诚可为鉴！ 
. Passage two: 且夫天下非小弱也，雍州之地，崤函之固，自若也。陈涉之位，非尊于齐、楚、燕、赵、韩、魏、宋、卫、中山之君也；锄櫌棘矜，非铦于钩戟长铩也；谪戍之众，非抗于九国之师也；深谋远虑，行军用兵之道，非及乡时之士也。然而成败异变，功业相反，何也？试使山东之国与陈涉度长絜大，比权量力，则不可同年而语矣。然秦以区区之地，致万乘之势，序八州而朝同列，百有余年矣；然后以六合为家，崤函为宫；一夫作难而七庙隳，身死人手，为天下笑者，何也？仁义不施而攻守之势异也。. Passage one: 行略定秦地。函谷关有兵守关，不得入。又闻沛公已破咸阳，项羽大怒，使当阳君等击关。项羽遂入，至于戏西。沛公军霸上，未得与项羽相见。沛公左司马曹无伤，使人言于项羽曰：“沛公欲王关中，使子婴为相，珍宝尽有之。”项羽大怒曰：“旦日飨士卒，为击破沛公军！”当是时，项羽兵四十万，在新丰鸿门；沛公兵十万，在霸上。范增说项羽曰：“沛公居山东时，贪于财货，好美姬。今入关，财物无所取，妇女无所幸，此其志不在小。吾令人望其气，皆为龙虎，成五采，此天子气也。急击勿失！”. Passage two: 项王闻沛公已破咸阳，欲王关中，大怒曰：“竖子！吾与之西入秦，破釜沉舟，与秦人血战，方得关中，而彼欲独擅之乎？”乃引兵东，欲击沛公。亚父谏曰：“沛公之志不在此，其志远大，非等闲之辈。今不击，必为后患！机不可失，时不再来，望君速断！”项王乃决意东进，与沛公决一死战。

Passage two: 行略定秦地。函谷关有兵守关，不得入。又闻沛公已破咸阳，项羽大怒，使当阳君等击关。项羽遂入，至于戏西。沛公军霸上，未得与项羽相见。沛公左司马曹无伤，使人言于项羽曰：“沛公欲王关中，使子婴为相，珍宝尽有之。”项羽大怒曰：“旦日飨士卒，为击破沛公军！”当是时，项羽兵四十万，在新丰鸿门；沛公兵十万，在霸上。范增说项羽曰：“沛公居山东时，贪于财货，好美姬。今入关，财物无所取，妇女无所幸，此其志不在小。吾令人望其气，皆为龙虎，成五采，此天子气也。急击勿失！”. Passage one: 其日牛马嘶，新妇入青庐。奄奄黄昏后，寂寂人定初。“我命绝今日，魂去尸长留！”揽裙脱丝履，举身赴清池。 府吏闻此事，心知长别离。徘徊庭树下，自挂东南枝。 两家求合葬，合葬华山傍。东西植松柏，左右种梧桐。枝枝相覆盖，叶叶相交通。中有双飞鸟，自名为鸳鸯。仰头相向鸣，夜夜达五更。行人驻足听，寡妇起彷徨。多谢后世人，戒之慎勿忘。. Passage two: 华陰有合葬墓，碑文漫漶，依稀可辨，曰：新婚燕爾，琴瑟和鳴。奈何世俗紛擾，門戶之見，鴛鴦被逐，同赴黃泉。今青山為證，松柏梧桐，交柯合抱，以慰其情。更有雙鴛鴦，自墓中翩翩飛出，哀鳴九天，聞者無不落淚。嗟乎！願天下有情人，莫效此等憾事，當珍惜眼前人，白首不相離。

. Passage two: 嗟乎！一人之心，千万人之心也。秦爱纷奢，人亦念其家。奈何取之尽锱铢，用之如泥沙？使负栋之柱，多于南亩之农夫；架梁之椽，多于机上之工女；钉头磷磷，多于在庾之粟粒；瓦缝参差，多于周身之帛缕；直栏横槛，多于九土之城郭；管弦呕哑，多于市人之言语。使天下之人，不敢言而敢怒。独夫之心，日益骄固。戍卒叫，函谷举，楚人一炬，可怜焦土！. Passage one: 积土成山，风雨兴焉；积水成渊，蛟龙生焉；积善成德，而神明自得，圣心备焉。故不积跬步，无以至千里；不积小流，无以成江海。骐骥一跃，不能十步；驽马十驾，功在不舍。锲而舍之，朽木不折；锲而不舍，金石可镂。蚓无爪牙之利，筋骨之强，上食埃土，下饮黄泉，用心一也。蟹六跪而二螯，非蛇鳝之穴无可寄托者，用心躁也。. Passage two: 是以庸人习之，恒可胜才；骐骥一跃，弗能十步。锲而舍之，朽木不折；锲而不舍，金石可镂。蚓无爪牙之利，筋骨之强，上食埃土，下饮黄泉，用心一也。蟹六跪而二螯，非蛇鳝之穴无可寄托者，用心躁也。故曰：天下无难事，唯坚忍者能成之。

. Passage two: 积土成山，风雨兴焉；积水成渊，蛟龙生焉；积善成德，而神明自得，圣心备焉。故不积跬步，无以至千里；不积小流，无以成江海。骐骥一跃，不能十步；驽马十驾，功在不舍。锲而舍之，朽木不折；锲而不舍，金石可镂。蚓无爪牙之利，筋骨之强，上食埃土，下饮黄泉，用心一也。蟹六跪而二螯，非蛇鳝之穴无可寄托者，用心躁也。. Passage one: 于是洛灵感焉，徙倚彷徨。神光离合，乍阴乍阳。竦轻躯以鹤立，若将飞而未翔。践椒涂之郁烈，步蘅薄而流芳。超长吟以永慕兮，声哀厉而弥长。尔乃众灵杂沓，命俦啸侣。或戏清流，或翔神渚，或采明珠，或拾翠羽。从南湘之二妃，携汉滨之游女。叹匏瓜之无匹兮，咏牵牛之独处。扬轻袿之猗靡兮，翳修袖以延伫。体迅飞凫，飘忽若神。凌波微步，罗袜生尘。动无常则，若危若安；进止难期，若往若还。转眄流精，光润玉颜。含辞未吐，气若幽兰。华容婀娜，令我忘餐。. Passage one: 柏子潭者，深谷幽壑之中也。潭水深邃，其色如墨，人言潭底有五龙祠，昔轩辕氏曾祷雨于此，灵验非常。潭之左右，奇石嶙峋，尤以双燕洞、南白鸽洞为胜。

潭西里许，一泓清泉，名曰让泉，泉水甘冽，沁人心脾。泉旁有亭，曰“渐入佳境”，惜已颓圮。淳熙年间，郡守张商卿携僚属游历至此，叹其景色之幽绝，纷纷题诗于亭壁之上，今墨迹斑驳，犹可辨认。 
. Passage two: 东南有柏子潭。潭在深谷底，延袤亩余，色正深黑。即欧阳公赛龙处，上有五龙祠。皇上初龙飞，屯兵于滁，会旱暵，亲挟雕弓，注矢于潭者三，约三日雨，如期果大雨。及御宝历，为作栏楯护潭，且新其庙。庙侧有时若亭。濂坐亭上，问潭侧双燕洞及其南白鸽洞，以肆穷览，人无知者，乃止。复西行约三里许，有泉泻出于两山之间，分流而下，曰让泉，潺潺清澈，可鉴毛发。傍岸有亭曰“渐入佳境”，今已废，惟四大字勒崖石间。淳熙中郡守张商卿等题名尚存。. Passage two: 东南有柏子潭。潭在深谷底，延袤亩余，色正深黑。即欧阳公赛龙处，上有五龙祠。皇上初龙飞，屯兵于滁，会旱暵，亲挟雕弓，注矢于潭者三，约三日雨，如期果大雨。及御宝历，为作栏楯护潭，且新其庙。庙侧有时若亭。濂坐亭上，问潭侧双燕洞及其南白鸽洞，以肆穷览，人无知者，乃止。复西行约三里许，有泉泻出于两山之间，分流而下，曰让泉，潺潺清澈，可鉴毛发。傍岸有亭曰“渐入佳境”，今已废，惟四大字勒崖石间。淳熙中郡守张商卿等题名尚存。. Passage one: 晋太元中，武陵人捕鱼为业。缘溪行，忘路之远近。忽逢桃花林，夹岸数百步，中无杂树，芳草鲜美，落英缤纷。渔人甚异之，复前行，欲穷其林。林尽水源，便得一山，山有小口，仿佛若有光。便舍船，从口入。初极狭，才通人。复行数十步，豁然开朗。土地平旷，屋舍俨然，有良田、美池、桑竹之属。阡陌交通，鸡犬相闻。其中往来种作，男女衣着，悉如外人。黄发垂髫，并怡然自乐。见渔人，乃大惊，问所从来。具答之。便要还家，设酒杀鸡作食。村中闻有此人，咸来问讯。自云先世避秦时乱，率妻子邑人来此绝境，不复出焉，遂与外人间隔。问今是何世，乃不知有汉，无论魏晋。此人一一为具言所闻，皆叹惋。余人各复延至其家，皆出酒食。停数日，辞去。此中人语云：“不足为外人道也。”既出，得其船，便扶向路，处处志之。及郡下，诣太守，说如此。太守即遣人随其往，寻向所志，遂迷，不复得路。南阳刘子骥，高尚士也，闻之，欣然规往。未果，寻病终。后遂无问津者。. Passage two: 晉太元年間，武陵漁郎緣溪捕魚，忽逢桃花夾岸，落英繽紛。心甚異之，遂捨舟溯源而上，欲窮其林。林盡處，見山有小口，彷彿若有光。便捨舟，從口入。

初極狹，纔通人。復行數十步，豁然開朗。土地平曠，屋舍儼然，有良田美池桑竹之屬。阡陌交通，雞犬相聞。其中往來種作，男女衣著，悉如外人。黃髮垂髫，并怡然自樂。

見漁人，乃大驚，問所從來。具答之。便要還家，設酒殺雞作食。村中聞有此人，咸來問訊。自云先世避秦時亂，率妻子邑人來此絕境，不復出焉，遂與外人間隔。問今是何世，乃不知有漢，無論魏晉。此人一一為具言所聞，皆嘆惋。

餘人各復延至其家，皆出酒食。停數日，辭去。此中人語云：「不足為外人道也。」

既出，得其船，便扶向路，處處志之。及郡下，詣太守，說如此。太守即遣人隨其往，尋向所誌，遂迷，不復得路。

南陽劉子驥，高尚之士也，聞之，欣然規往。未果，尋病終。後遂無問津者。

Passage one: 庆历四年春，滕子京谪守巴陵郡。越明年，政通人和，百废具兴，乃重修岳阳楼，增其旧制，刻唐贤今人诗赋于其上，属予作文以记之。予观夫巴陵胜状，在洞庭一湖。衔远山，吞长江，浩浩汤汤，横无际涯，朝晖夕阴，气象万千，此则岳阳楼之大观也，前人之述备矣。然则北通巫峡，南极潇湘，迁客骚人，多会于此，览物之情，得无异乎？若夫淫雨霏霏，连月不开，阴风怒号，浊浪排空，日星隐曜，山岳潜形，商旅不行，樯倾楫摧，薄暮冥冥，虎啸猿啼。登斯楼也，则有去国怀乡，忧谗畏讥，满目萧然，感极而悲者矣。至若春和景明，波澜不惊，上下天光，一碧万顷，沙鸥翔集，锦鳞游泳，岸芷汀兰，郁郁青青。而或长烟一空，皓月千里，浮光跃金，静影沉璧，渔歌互答，此乐何极！登斯楼也，则有心旷神怡，宠辱偕忘，把酒临风，其喜洋洋者矣。嗟夫！予尝求古仁人之心，或异二者之为，何哉？不以物喜，不以己悲，居庙堂之高则忧其民，处江湖之远则忧其君。是进亦忧，退亦忧。然则何时而乐耶？其必曰“先天下之忧而忧，后天下之乐而乐”乎！噫！微斯人，吾谁与归？时六年九月十五日。. Passage two: 庆历四年春，滕子京谪守巴陵郡。越明年，政通人和，百废具兴，乃重修岳阳楼，增其旧制，刻唐贤今人诗赋于其上。属予作文以记之。

嗟夫！夫岳阳楼之大观，天下罕比。登斯楼也，则有心旷神怡，宠辱皆忘，把酒临风，其喜洋洋者矣。

北通巫峡，南极潇湘，浩浩汤汤，横无际涯。朝晖夕阴，气象万千。此则岳阳楼之大观也，前人之述备矣。然则北通巫峡，南极潇湘，迁客骚人，多会于此，览物之情，得无异乎？

若夫霪雨霏霏，连月不开；阴风怒号，浊浪排空；日星隐耀，山岳潜形；商旅不行，樯倾楫摧；薄暮冥冥，虎啸猿啼。登斯楼也，则有去国怀乡，忧谗畏讥，满目萧然，感极而悲者矣。

至若春和景明，波澜不惊，上下天光，一碧万顷；沙鸥翔集，锦鳞游泳；岸芷汀兰，郁郁青青。而或长烟一空，皓月千里，浮光跃金，静影沉璧，渔歌互答，此乐何极！登斯楼也，则有心旷神怡，宠辱皆忘，把酒临风，其喜洋洋者矣。

嗟夫！予尝求古仁人之心，或异二者之为，何哉？不以物喜，不以己悲。居庙堂之高，则忧其民；处江湖之远，则忧其君。是进亦忧，退亦忧。然则何时而乐耶？其必曰：先天下之忧而忧，后天下之乐而乐乎！噫！微斯人，吾谁与归？

Passage one: 环滁皆山也。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行六七里，渐闻水声潺潺，而泻出于两峰之间者，酿泉也。峰回路转，有亭翼然临于泉上者，醉翁亭也。作亭者谁？山之僧智仙也。名之者谁？太守自谓也。太守与客来饮于此，饮少辄醉，而年又最高，故自号曰醉翁也。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。若夫日出而林霏开，云归而岩穴暝，晦明变化者，山间之朝暮也。野芳发而幽香，佳木秀而繁阴，风霜高洁，水落而石出者，山间之四时也。朝而往，暮而归，四时之景不同，而乐亦无穷也。至于负者歌于途，行者休于树，前者呼，后者应，伛偻提携，往来而不绝者，滁人游也。临溪而渔，溪深而鱼肥，酿泉为酒，泉香而酒洌，山肴野蔌，杂然而前陈者，太守宴也。宴酣之乐，非丝非竹，射者中，弈者胜，觥筹交错，起坐而喧哗者，众宾欢也。苍颜白发，颓然乎其间者，太守醉也。已而夕阳在山，人影散乱，太守归而宾客从也。树林阴翳，鸣声上下，游人去而禽鸟乐也。然而禽鸟知山林之乐，而不知人之乐；人知从太守游而乐，而不知太守之乐其乐也。醉能同其乐，醒能述以文者，太守也。太守谓谁？庐陵欧阳修也。. Passage two: 琅琊胜境，山水清嘉。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行数里，有一亭，翼然临于泉上，名曰醉翁亭。醉翁者，谁欤？太守自谓也。

夫滁之山水，秀丽天成，四时之景，皆有可观。春时，山岚氤氲，花木繁盛，鸟语啁啾，溪流淙淙，游人如织，踏青赏春，其乐融融。夏日，绿树成荫，浓荫蔽日，凉风习习，泉水清冽，消暑纳凉，心旷神怡。秋来，层林尽染，红叶飘零，山色如画，秋高气爽，登高望远，令人心胸开阔。冬至，白雪皑皑，银装素裹，玉树琼枝，静谧肃穆，踏雪寻梅，别有一番情趣。

醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。太守与客来饮于此，饮酒乐甚，扣舷而歌之，歌曰：“醉翁醉翁，醉心于山水中也。”

观夫，山之高耸，峰回路转，林木葱郁，泉水叮咚，皆是大自然之鬼斧神工，令人叹为观止。太守寄情山水，以文会友，乐而忘返。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。盖言太守虽醉，实则心醉于山水之间，陶醉于自然之美景，忘却尘世烦忧，获得精神上的愉悦和心灵上的慰藉。

呜呼！山水之乐，与民同乐，此乃太守之胸襟，亦是人之本性也。太守以其敏锐的观察力、细腻的笔触，将琅琊山之美景与醉翁亭之雅致描绘得淋漓尽致，更将人与自然和谐相处的景象展现得生动形象，令人读之如临其境，如痴如醉。

Passage two: 环滁皆山也。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行六七里，渐闻水声潺潺，而泻出于两峰之间者，酿泉也。峰回路转，有亭翼然临于泉上者，醉翁亭也。作亭者谁？山之僧智仙也。名之者谁？太守自谓也。太守与客来饮于此，饮少辄醉，而年又最高，故自号曰醉翁也。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。若夫日出而林霏开，云归而岩穴暝，晦明变化者，山间之朝暮也。野芳发而幽香，佳木秀而繁阴，风霜高洁，水落而石出者，山间之四时也。朝而往，暮而归，四时之景不同，而乐亦无穷也。至于负者歌于途，行者休于树，前者呼，后者应，伛偻提携，往来而不绝者，滁人游也。临溪而渔，溪深而鱼肥，酿泉为酒，泉香而酒洌，山肴野蔌，杂然而前陈者，太守宴也。宴酣之乐，非丝非竹，射者中，弈者胜，觥筹交错，起坐而喧哗者，众宾欢也。苍颜白发，颓然乎其间者，太守醉也。已而夕阳在山，人影散乱，太守归而宾客从也。树林阴翳，鸣声上下，游人去而禽鸟乐也。然而禽鸟知山林之乐，而不知人之乐；人知从太守游而乐，而不知太守之乐其乐也。醉能同其乐，醒能述以文者，太守也。太守谓谁？庐陵欧阳修也。. Passage two: 琅琊胜境，山水清嘉。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行数里，有一亭，翼然临于泉上，名曰醉翁亭。醉翁者，谁欤？太守自谓也。

夫滁之山水，秀丽天成，四时之景，皆有可观。春时，山岚氤氲，花木繁盛，鸟语啁啾，溪流淙淙，游人如织，踏青赏春，其乐融融。夏日，绿树成荫，浓荫蔽日，凉风习习，泉水清冽，消暑纳凉，心旷神怡。秋来，层林尽染，红叶飘零，山色如画，秋高气爽，登高望远，令人心胸开阔。冬至，白雪皑皑，银装素裹，玉树琼枝，静谧肃穆，踏雪寻梅，别有一番情趣。

醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。太守与客来饮于此，饮酒乐甚，扣舷而歌之，歌曰：“醉翁醉翁，醉心于山水中也。”

观夫，山之高耸，峰回路转，林木葱郁，泉水叮咚，皆是大自然之鬼斧神工，令人叹为观止。太守寄情山水，以文会友，乐而忘返。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。盖言太守虽醉，实则心醉于山水之间，陶醉于自然之美景，忘却尘世烦忧，获得精神上的愉悦和心灵上的慰藉。

Passage one: 余告之曰：其形也，翩若惊鸿，婉若游龙。荣曜秋菊，华茂春松。髣髴兮若轻云之蔽月，飘飖兮若流风之回雪。远而望之，皎若太阳升朝霞；迫而察之，灼若芙蕖出渌波。穠纤得衷，修短合度。肩若削成，腰如约素。延颈秀项，皓质呈露。芳泽无加，铅华弗御。云髻峨峨，修眉联娟。丹唇外朗，皓齿内鲜。明眸善睐，靥辅承权。瓌姿艳逸，仪静体闲。柔情绰态，媚于语言。奇服旷世，骨像应图。披罗衣之璀粲兮，珥瑶碧之华琚。戴金翠之首饰，缀明珠以耀躯。践远游之文履，曳雾绡之轻裾。微幽兰之芳蔼兮，步踟蹰于山隅。于是忽焉纵体，以遨以嬉。左倚采旄，右荫桂旗。攘皓腕于神浒兮，采湍濑之玄芝。. Passage two: 伊人者，姿容秀美，世所罕见。其体态轻盈，若鸿鹄之蹁跹，似游龙之婉转。面若桃花，肤如凝脂，顾盼之间，光彩照人。其举止优雅，落落大方，一颦一笑皆动人心魄。衣裳华美，佩饰精致，步履轻盈，宛若仙子下凡尘。睹其容颜，令人心驰神往；闻其声，如听天籁之音。世间竟有如此尤物，真乃天公之造化，令人叹为观止。

Passage one: 夫天地浩瀚，其间充盈一气，曰正气。此气也，上则为日月星辰，垂光明于宇宙；下则为山川河岳，布精气于八方。其形虽殊，其本则一，皆正气之所化也。

於人而言，此气化为浩然之气，充塞天地，无所不在。夫子曰：“岁寒，然后知松柏之后凋也。”此正气之体现也。古之仁人志士，皆以正气立身，以正气行事。岳武穆精忠报国，文丞相舍生取义，皆赖正气之支撑，其精神方能千古流传，万世敬仰。

余虽才疏学浅，命途多舛，身陷囹圄，然心之所向，皆为此正气耳。古人云：“天将降大任于斯人也，必先苦其心志，劳其筋骨，饿其体肤，空乏其身，行拂乱其所为，所以动心忍性，曾益其所不能。”余深信，只要心怀正气，则穷途末路亦可柳暗花明，困顿窘迫亦可逢凶化吉。

故吾辈当以古人为楷模，涵养正气，弘扬正道，如此，方可不负此生，不负天地！ 
. Passage one: 天地有正气，杂然赋流形。下则为河岳，上则为日星。于人曰浩然，沛乎塞苍冥。皇路当清夷，含和吐明庭。时穷节乃见，一一垂丹青。在齐太史简，在晋董狐笔。在秦张良椎，在汉苏武节。为严将军头，为嵇侍中血。为张睢阳齿，为颜常山舌。或为辽东帽，清操厉冰雪。或为出师表，鬼神泣壮烈。或为渡江楫，慷慨吞胡羯。或为击贼笏，逆竖头破裂。是气所磅礴，凛烈万古存。当其贯日月，生死安足论。地维赖以立，天柱赖以尊。三纲实系命，道义为之根。嗟予遘阳九，隶也实不力。楚囚缨其冠，传车送穷北。鼎镬甘如饴，求之不可得。阴房阗鬼火，春院閟天黑。(阗 一作：阒)牛骥同一皂，鸡栖凤凰食。一朝蒙雾露，分作沟中瘠。如此再寒暑，百沴自辟易。嗟哉沮洳场，为我安乐国。岂有他缪巧，阴阳不能贼。顾此耿耿在，仰视浮云白。悠悠我心悲，苍天曷有极。哲人日已远，典刑在夙昔。风檐展书读，古道照颜色。. 余虽才疏学浅，命途多舛，身陷囹圄，然心之所向，皆为此正气耳。古人云：“天将降大任于斯人也，必先苦其心志，劳其筋骨，饿其体肤，空乏其身，行拂乱其所为，所以动心忍性，曾益其所不能。”余深信，只要心怀正气，则穷途末路亦可柳暗花明，困顿窘迫亦可逢凶化吉。

Passage one: 于是张良至军门见樊哙。樊哙曰：“今日之事何如？”良曰：“甚急！今者项庄拔剑舞，其意常在沛公也。”哙曰：“此迫矣！臣请入，与之同命。”哙即带剑拥盾入军门。交戟之卫士欲止不内，樊哙侧其盾以撞，卫士仆地，哙遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目视项王，头发上指，目眦尽裂。项王按剑而跽曰：“客何为者？”张良曰：“沛公之参乘樊哙者也。”项王曰：“壮士！赐之卮酒。”则与斗卮酒。哙拜谢，起，立而饮之。项王曰：“赐之彘肩。”则与一生彘肩。樊哙覆其盾于地，加彘肩上，拔剑切而啖之。项王曰：“壮士！能复饮乎？”樊哙曰：“臣死且不避，卮酒安足辞！夫秦王有虎狼之心，杀人如不能举，刑人如恐不胜，天下皆叛之。怀王与诸将约曰：‘先破秦入咸阳者王之。’今沛公先破秦入咸阳，毫毛不敢有所近，封闭宫室，还军霸上，以待大王来。故遣将守关者，备他盗出入与非常也。劳苦而功高如此，未有封侯之赏，而听细说，欲诛有功之人，此亡秦之续耳。窃为大王不取也！”项王未有以应，曰：“坐。”樊哙从良坐。坐须臾，沛公起如厕，因招樊哙出。. Passage one: 妾自嫁入君家，如藤攀树，愿得共荣。奈何姑母素来不喜，视妾如草芥，言语冷淡，目光如霜。妾日夜侍奉，谨言慎行，唯恐行差踏错，招致责骂。然则人心难测，妾之卑微，不足以消解偏见，反倒令姑母愈加厌恶。

每每思及此处，心中便如刀绞，泪湿衣襟。君虽怜惜，亦是无可奈何。长此以往，妾如困兽，在这深宅大院中，不见天日，唯有无尽的煎熬。妾并非贪图富贵之人，亦不奢求荣华一生，只愿寻一安身之所，得一真心相待之人。然如今看来，此愿于妾，竟是奢望。

今日，姑母终是提出，令妾归家。君闻之，勃然大怒，与姑母争执不下。妾知君心意，心中感激，然则覆水难收，木已成舟，妾之命运，如同风中浮萍，身不由己。

回首往昔，与君相遇，情投意合，琴瑟和鸣，宛如昨日。如今劳燕分飞，各奔东西，此去经年，不知何时才能相见。妾此番离去，只愿君珍重自身，勿以妾为念。望君日后觅得贤妻，相夫教子，白头偕老，莫要辜负这大好年华。妾虽有万般不舍，亦只能化作一声叹息，从此天涯陌路，各自安好。 
. Passage two: “十三能织素，十四学裁衣。十五弹箜篌，十六诵诗书。十七为君妇，心中常苦悲。君既为府吏，守节情不移。贱妾留空房，相见常日稀。鸡鸣入机织，夜夜不得息。三日断五匹，大人故嫌迟。非为织作迟，君家妇难为！妾不堪驱使，徒留无所施。便可白公姥，及时相遣归。” 府吏得闻之，堂上启阿母：“儿已薄禄相，幸复得此妇。结发同枕席，黄泉共为友。共事二三年，始尔未为久。女行无偏斜，何意致不厚。” 阿母谓府吏：“何乃太区区！此妇无礼节，举动自专由。吾意久怀忿，汝岂得自由！东家有贤女，自名秦罗敷。可怜体无比，阿母为汝求。便可速遣之，遣去慎莫留！” 府吏长跪告：“伏惟启阿母。今若遣此妇，终老不复取！” 阿母得闻之，槌床便大怒：“小子无所畏，何敢助妇语！吾已失恩义，会不相从许！” 府吏默无声，再拜还入户。举言谓新妇，哽咽不能语：“我自不驱卿，逼迫有阿母。卿但暂还家，吾今且报府。不久当归还，还必相迎取。以此下心意，慎勿违吾语。” 新妇谓府吏：“勿复重纷纭。往昔初阳岁，谢家来贵门。奉事循公姥，进止敢自专？昼夜勤作息，伶俜萦苦辛。谓言无罪过，供养卒大恩；仍更被驱遣，何言复来还！妾有绣腰襦，葳蕤自生光；红罗复斗帐，四角垂香囊；箱帘六七十，绿碧青丝绳，物物各自异，种种在其中。人贱物亦鄙，不足迎后人，留待作遗施，于今无会因。时时为安慰，久久莫相忘！”. 回首往昔，与君相遇，情投意合，琴瑟和鸣，宛如昨日。如今劳燕分飞，各奔东西，此去经年，不知何时才能相见。妾此番离去，只愿君珍重自身，勿以妾为念。望君日后觅得贤妻，相夫教子，白头偕老，莫要辜负这大好年华。妾虽有万般不舍，亦只能化作一声叹息，从此天涯陌路，各自安好。 
. Passage two: “十三能织素，十四学裁衣。十五弹箜篌，十六诵诗书。十七为君妇，心中常苦悲。君既为府吏，守节情不移。贱妾留空房，相见常日稀。鸡鸣入机织，夜夜不得息。三日断五匹，大人故嫌迟。非为织作迟，君家妇难为！妾不堪驱使，徒留无所施。便可白公姥，及时相遣归。” 府吏得闻之，堂上启阿母：“儿已薄禄相，幸复得此妇。结发同枕席，黄泉共为友。共事二三年，始尔未为久。女行无偏斜，何意致不厚。” 阿母谓府吏：“何乃太区区！此妇无礼节，举动自专由。吾意久怀忿，汝岂得自由！东家有贤女，自名秦罗敷。可怜体无比，阿母为汝求。便可速遣之，遣去慎莫留！” 府吏长跪告：“伏惟启阿母。今若遣此妇，终老不复取！” 阿母得闻之，槌床便大怒：“小子无所畏，何敢助妇语！吾已失恩义，会不相从许！” 府吏默无声，再拜还入户。举言谓新妇，哽咽不能语：“我自不驱卿，逼迫有阿母。卿但暂还家，吾今且报府。不久当归还，还必相迎取。以此下心意，慎勿违吾语。” 新妇谓府吏：“勿复重纷纭。往昔初阳岁，谢家来贵门。奉事循公姥，进止敢自专？昼夜勤作息，伶俜萦苦辛。谓言无罪过，供养卒大恩；仍更被驱遣，何言复来还！妾有绣腰襦，葳蕤自生光；红罗复斗帐，四角垂香囊；箱帘六七十，绿碧青丝绳，物物各自异，种种在其中。人贱物亦鄙，不足迎后人，留待作遗施，于今无会因。时时为安慰，久久莫相忘！”. Passage one: 六王毕，四海一，蜀山兀，阿房出。覆压三百余里，隔离天日。骊山北构而西折，直走咸阳。二川溶溶，流入宫墙。五步一楼，十步一阁；廊腰缦回，檐牙高啄；各抱地势，钩心斗角。盘盘焉，囷囷焉，蜂房水涡，矗不知其几千万落。长桥卧波，未云何龙？复道行空，不霁何虹？高低冥迷，不知西东。歌台暖响，春光融融；舞殿冷袖，风雨凄凄。一日之内，一宫之间，而气候不齐。
妃嫔媵嫱，王子皇孙，辞楼下殿，辇来于秦。朝歌夜弦，为秦宫人。明星荧荧，开妆镜也；绿云扰扰，梳晓鬟也；渭流涨腻，弃脂水也；烟斜雾横，焚椒兰也。雷霆乍惊，宫车过也；辘辘远听，杳不知其所之也。一肌一容，尽态极妍，缦立远视，而望幸焉。有不见者，三十六年。燕赵之收藏，韩魏之经营，齐楚之精英，几世几年，剽掠其人，倚叠如山。一旦不能有，输来其间。鼎铛玉石，金块珠砾，弃掷逦迤，秦人视之，亦不甚惜。. Passage two: 阿房宫者，秦之瑰宝，天下奇观也。其宫殿之巍峨，楼阁之高耸，皆世所罕见。东西五百步，南北五十丈，上可通天，下可蔽日，真乃人间仙境也。宫内雕梁画栋，金碧辉煌，珍宝奇玩，不可胜数。丝绸锦缎，堆积如山；美酒佳肴，日夜不绝。歌姬舞女，翩若惊鸿，婉若游龙，歌舞升平，纸醉金迷。

秦王日坐朝堂，夜宿寝宫，皆有侍卫护驾，宫娥服侍，极尽奢华之能事。四方珍奇，源源不断地运入宫中，以供秦王享乐。然乐极生悲，物极必反，秦王只顾贪图享乐，不顾百姓疾苦，终招致天下大乱。

昔日繁华之阿房宫，如今只剩残垣断壁，荒草丛生，一片凄凉。昔日歌舞升平之声，如今已被寒风呼啸之声所取代。秦之兴衰，如同一场盛大而短暂的烟火，最终归于寂灭。其教训之深刻，值得后世深思。

Passage one: 乾隆三十九年冬，余自京师启程，一路南下，经郭北，过临清，复渡黄河，抵鲁地。时值隆冬，朔风凛冽，然心中向往泰山之雄伟，不以为苦。

抵泰安州，稍作休整，便雇脚夫，备干粮，次日清晨，由岱宗坊启程登山。一路拾级而上，但见路旁青松翠柏，枝干虬曲，傲然挺立，似在欢迎远道而来之人。山路崎岖，愈往上行，愈觉山势陡峭，云雾缭绕。回首望去，山下城郭田畴，尽收眼底，宛如一幅水墨画卷。

行至中天门，已是日暮时分，遂借宿山间道观。是夜，寒风呼啸，窗外松涛阵阵，更兼山月皎洁，映照白雪皑皑，别有一番景致。翌日凌晨，摸黑起身，手扶铁链，踏着积雪，艰难攀登，终至玉皇顶。

立于峰巅，但见东方天际渐露鱼肚白，继而霞光万道，染红半边天空。少顷，一轮红日喷薄而出，光芒四射，照耀山河。举目远眺，云海茫茫，群峰起伏，犹如波涛汹涌，蔚为壮观。极目南天，隐约可见黄河如练，奔流不息。俯瞰山下，则见泰城如豆，道路如丝，更觉此山之雄伟，天地之广阔。

下山途中，细观山间景致，怪石嶙峋，形态各异，或如猛虎下山，或似雄鹰展翅，令人叹为观止。更有古木参天，枝繁叶茂，遮天蔽日，为这冬日增添了几分生机。山间寺庙道观，香火鼎盛，碑刻题字，琳琅满目，无不彰显着泰山数千年来的文化底蕴。

是行也，余感触良多。泰山之雄伟壮丽，令人心胸开阔，豪情满怀；泰山之厚重文化，令人心生敬畏，发思古之幽情。愿他日再登泰山，领略其四季不同之美景。 
. Passage two: 余以乾隆三十九年十二月，自京师乘风雪，历齐河、长清，穿泰山西北谷，越长城之限，至于泰安。是月丁未，与知府朱孝纯子颍由南麓登。四十五里，道皆砌石为磴，其级七千有余。泰山正南面有三谷。中谷绕泰安城下，郦道元所谓环水也。余始循以入，道少半，越中岭，复循西谷，遂至其巅。古时登山，循东谷入，道有天门。东谷者，古谓之天门溪水，余所不至也。今所经中岭及山巅，崖限当道者，世皆谓之天门云。道中迷雾冰滑，磴几不可登。及既上，苍山负雪，明烛天南。望晚日照城郭，汶水、徂徕如画，而半山居雾若带然。 戊申晦，五鼓，与子颍坐日观亭，待日出。大风扬积雪击面。亭东自足下皆云漫。稍见云中白若樗蒱数十立者，山也。极天云一线异色，须臾成五采。日上，正赤如丹，下有红光动摇承之。或曰，此东海也。回视日观以西峰，或得日或否，绛皓驳色，而皆若偻。 亭西有岱祠，又有碧霞元君祠。皇帝行宫在碧霞元君祠东。是日观道中石刻，自唐显庆以来；其远古刻尽漫失。僻不当道者，皆不及往。 山多石，少土。石苍黑色，多平方，少圜。少杂树，多松，生石罅，皆平顶。冰雪，无瀑水，无鸟兽音迹。至日观数里内无树，而雪与人膝齐。 桐城姚鼐记。. Passage two: 乾隆三十九年冬，余自京师启程，一路南下，经郭北，过临清，复渡黄河，抵鲁地。时值隆冬，朔风凛冽，然心中向往泰山之雄伟，不以为苦。

抵泰安州，稍作休整，便雇脚夫，备干粮，次日清晨，由岱宗坊启程登山。一路拾级而上，但见路旁青松翠柏，枝干虬曲，傲然挺立，似在欢迎远道而来之人。山路崎岖，愈往上行，愈觉山势陡峭，云雾缭绕。回首望去，山下城郭田畴，尽收眼底，宛如一幅水墨画卷。

行至中天门，已是日暮时分，遂借宿山间道观。是夜，寒风呼啸，窗外松涛阵阵，更兼山月皎洁，映照白雪皑皑，别有一番景致。翌日凌晨，摸黑起身，手扶铁链，踏着积雪，艰难攀登，终至玉皇顶。

立于峰巅，但见东方天际渐露鱼肚白，继而霞光万道，染红半边天空。少顷，一轮红日喷薄而出，光芒四射，照耀山河。举目远眺，云海茫茫，群峰起伏，犹如波涛汹涌，蔚为壮观。极目南天，隐约可见黄河如练，奔流不息。俯瞰山下，则见泰城如豆，道路如丝，更觉此山之雄伟，天地之广阔。

下山途中，细观山间景致，怪石嶙峋，形态各异，或如猛虎下山，或似雄鹰展翅，令人叹为观止。更有古木参天，枝繁叶茂，遮天蔽日，为这冬日增添了几分生机。山间寺庙道观，香火鼎盛，碑刻题字，琳琅满目，无不彰显着泰山数千年来的文化底蕴。

是行也，余感触良多。泰山之雄伟壮丽，令人心胸开阔，豪情满怀；泰山之厚重文化，令人心生敬畏，发思古之幽情。愿他日再登泰山，领略其四季不同之美景。

Being mechanical, you ought not walk

Passage one: The country is in a dire state, suffering under the heavy hand of tyranny. The land is scarred by ongoing oppression and the wounds inflicted by the current ruler. One character, torn by the temptations of power, expresses a deep reluctance to become a villain. Malcolm, another character, acknowledges the nation's suffering and the tyranny that grips it. He points out that even with support from England and the possibility of overthrowing the current tyrant, there is a fear that the future ruler might bring even more vices and suffering. The uncertainty of what lies ahead weighs heavily on their minds, as they grapple with the hope for liberation and the dread of potential new evils.. Passage two: Bleed, bleed, poor country!
Great tyranny, lay thou thy basis sure,
For goodness dare not check thee! wear thou thy wrongs;
The title is affeer’d.—Fare thee well, lord:
I would not be the villain that thou think’st
For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp
And the rich East to boot.
MALCOLM.
Be not offended:
I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
I think our country sinks beneath the yoke;
It weeps, it bleeds; and each new day a gash
Is added to her wounds. I think, withal,
There would be hands uplifted in my right;
And here, from gracious England, have I offer
Of goodly thousands: but, for all this,
When I shall tread upon the tyrant’s head,
Or wear it on my sword, yet my poor country
Shall have more vices than it had before,
More suffer, and more sundry ways than ever,
By him that shall succeed.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
URSULA.
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
HERO.
So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord.
URSULA.
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
HERO.
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
URSULA.
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
HERO.. Passage two: Hero and Ursula are talking about Beatrice and Benedick's feelings for each other. Passage one: My Lord, in token of my true humilitie,
And simple meaning to your Majestie,
I kisse your graces hand, and take my leave,
Intending to dislodge my campe with speed.
KING. Then farwell Guise, the King and thou art freends.
Exit Guise.
EPERNOUNE. But trust him not my Lord,
For had your highnesse seene with what a pompe
He entred Paris, and how the Citizens
With gifts and shewes did entertaine him
And promised to be at his commaund:
Nay, they fear'd not to speak in the streetes,
That Guise ch, durst stand in armes against the King,
For not effecting of his holines will.
KING. Did they of Paris entertaine him so?
Then meanes he present treason to our state.
Well, let me alone, whose within there?. Passage two: Guise, showing humility and loyalty, bids the King farewell and promises to swiftly move his camp. However, Epernoune cautions the King against trusting Guise, pointing out the grand reception Guise received from the citizens of Paris, who seem to favor him over the King. This suggests potential treason. The King acknowledges the threat and decides to address the situation.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: Hung with hard ice-flakes, where hail-scur flew,
There I heard naught save the harsh sea
And ice-cold wave, at whiles the swan cries,
Did for my games the gannet’s clamour,
Sea-fowls, loudness was for me laughter,
The mews' singing all my mead-drink.
Storms, on the stone-cliffs beaten, fell on the stern
In icy feathers; full oft the eagle screamed
With spray on his pinion.
Not any protector
May make merry man faring needy.
This he little believes, who aye in winsome life
Abides ’mid burghers some heavy business,
Wealthy and wine-flushed, how I weary oft
Must bide above brine.. Passage two: The seafarer's life is one of relentless struggle against the elements. He battles the biting cold, the relentless ice, and the fury of storms. This starkly contrasts with the lives of those who dwell in comfort, blissfully unaware of such hardships. While they enjoy warmth and security, the seafarer endures a lonely and unforgiving world, highlighting the vast differences in human experiences.. You have been shown two different passages. the song of the two of us.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Unless the mind had a distinct perception of different objects and their qualities, it would be capable of very little knowledge, though the bodies that affect us were as busy about us as they are now, and the mind were continually employed in thinking. Passage one: Ithamore recounted his dark past to his master, Barabas, detailing his cruel deeds such as burning Christian villages, chaining eunuchs, and binding galley slaves. He also spoke of his time as an inn hostler where he would murder travelers and a prank in Jerusalem that injured pilgrims. Barabas, impressed by Ithamore's malevolence, acknowledged their shared hatred towards Christians and promised him gold in exchange for his loyalty and secrecy. Together, they prepared for the arrival of Don Lodowick.. Passage two: But tell me now, how hast thou spent thy time?
ITHAMORE. Faith, master,
In setting Christian villages on fire,
haining of eunuchs, binding galley-slaves.
One time I was an hostler in an inn,
And in the night-time secretly would I steal
To travellers' chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneel'd,
I strewed powder on the marble stones,
And therewithal their knees would rankle so,
That I have laugh'd a-good to see the cripples
Go limping home to Christendom on stilts.
BARABAS. Why, this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villains both;
Both circumcised; we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret; thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside; here comes Don Lodowick.. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: Of Man’s first disobedience, and the fruit
Of that forbidden tree whose mortal taste
Brought death into the World, and all our woe,
With loss of Eden, till one greater Man
Restore us, and regain the blissful seat,
Sing, Heavenly Muse, that, on the secret top
Of Oreb, or of Sinai, didst inspire
That shepherd who first taught the chosen seed
In the beginning how the heavens and earth
Rose out of Chaos: or, if Sion hill
Delight thee more, and Siloa’s brook that flowed
Fast by the oracle of God, I thence
Invoke thy aid to my adventurous song,
That with no middle flight intends to soar
Above th’ Aonian mount, while it pursues
Things unattempted yet in prose or rhyme.
And chiefly thou, O Spirit, that dost prefer
Before all temples th’ upright heart and pure,
Instruct me, for thou know’st; thou from the first
Wast present, and, with mighty wings outspread,
Dove-like sat’st brooding on the vast Abyss,
And mad’st it pregnant: what in me is dark
Illumine, what is low raise and support;
That, to the height of this great argument,
I may assert Eternal Providence,
And justify the ways of God to men.
Say first—for Heaven hides nothing from thy view,
Nor the deep tract of Hell—say first what cause
Moved our grand parents, in that happy state,
Favoured of Heaven so highly, to fall off
From their Creator, and transgress his will
For one restraint, lords of the World besides.
Who first seduced them to that foul revolt?. Passage two: In the beginning of this poem, we delve into the story of Adam and Eve, the first humans, whose disobedience by eating the forbidden fruit brought death and suffering into the world, leading to the loss of Eden. The author calls upon the Heavenly Muse and the Holy Spirit for inspiration in crafting a poem that aims to explain and justify God's ways to humanity. This passage seeks to understand why Adam and Eve, who were in a state of blessing, chose to defy their Creator and succumb to temptation.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: Sir, I will answer anything. But I beseech you,
If ’t be your pleasure, and most wise consent,
(As partly I find it is) that your fair daughter,
At this odd-even and dull watch o’ the night,
Transported with no worse nor better guard,
But with a knave of common hire, a gondolier,
To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor:
If this be known to you, and your allowance,
We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs.
But if you know not this, my manners tell me,
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That from the sense of all civility,
I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Your daughter (if you have not given her leave)
I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself:
If she be in her chamber or your house,
Let loose on me the justice of the state
For thus deluding you.
BRABANTIO.
Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper! Call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light, I say, light!. Passage two: A man approaches Brabantio with urgent news, telling him that his daughter has run away with a Moor in the dead of night, accompanied only by a humble gondolier. Passage one: How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.. Passage two: In our quest to understand and distinguish ideas accurately, we often face numerous challenges. These difficulties stem from various sources, such as the inherent limitations of our senses, a lack of mental sharpness, and a tendency to rush through our thoughts. The ability to discern ideas clearly is crucial for sound judgment and reasoning. However, it's important to recognize that having a quick wit and a good memory doesn't necessarily equate to possessing clear judgment or deep reasoning skills. Wit is about quickly assembling agreeable ideas, while judgment requires the careful separation of distinct ideas. The immediate appeal of wit can be enticing, but true understanding demands a more laborious process of deeper analysis. Superficial pleasure from quick wit is no substitute for the profound insights gained through careful and deliberate judgment.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: Tamburlaine stood tall, exuding an aura of unmatched power and dominance. He boasted about his unparalleled influence over emperors, claiming to be the most radiant force on earth, capable of controlling even the celestial bodies. With a proud and commanding tone, he recounted his recent military conquest in Bithynia, detailing the sheer devastation his forces had wrought. He warned that Persia and other regions would soon face a similar fate, crushed under the might of his unstoppable army. Zabina, filled with scorn and disdain, condemned Tamburlaine for his cruelty and unlawful actions. She accused him of usurping the Persian throne without any right and mistreating her captive husband, a true emperor who had once commanded great respect and admiration. Her words dripped with contempt as she lamented the fall of a noble ruler at the hands of a ruthless conqueror.. Passage two: TAMBURLAINE. Now clear the triple region of the air,
And let the Majesty of Heaven behold
Their scourge and terror tread on emperors.
Smile, stars that reign'd at my nativity,
And dim the brightness of your neighbour lamps;
Disdain to borrow light of Cynthia!
For I, the chiefest lamp of all the earth,
First rising in the east with mild aspect,
But fixed now in the meridian line,
Will send up fire to your turning spheres,
And cause the sun to borrow light of you.
My sword struck fire from his coat of steel,
Even in Bithynia, when I took this Turk;
As when a fiery exhalation,
Wrapt in the bowels of a freezing cloud,
Fighting for passage, make[s] the welkin crack,
And casts a flash of lightning to the earth:
But, ere I march to wealthy Persia,
Or leave Damascus and th' Egyptian fields,
As was the fame of Clymene's brain-sick son
That almost brent the axle-tree of heaven,
So shall our swords, our lances, and our shot
Fill all the air with fiery meteors;
Then, when the sky shall wax as red as blood,
It shall be said I made it red myself,
To make me think of naught but blood and war.
ZABINA. Unworthy king, that by thy cruelty
Unlawfully usurp'st the Persian seat,
Dar'st thou, that never saw an emperor
Before thou met my husband in the field,
Being thy captive, thus abuse his state,
Keeping his kingly body in a cage,
That roofs of gold and sun-bright palaces
Should have prepar'd to entertain his grace?
And treading him beneath thy loathsome feet,
Whose feet the kings of Africa have kiss'd?. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: Pandarus was determined to bring Troilus and Cressida together. He convinced Deiphobus, Troilus' brother, to invite Cressida to dinner by telling him that she needed protection from Polyphete. Deiphobus agreed and got the support of Hector and Helen. Meanwhile, Pandarus told Troilus to stay at Deiphobus' house and pretend to be ill. At the dinner, Helen and Pandarus praised Troilus, making Cressida feel proud of his love for her. During the gathering, Pandarus suggested that Cressida explain her situation directly to Troilus. He then arranged for Helen and Deiphobus to be occupied with some documents, while he brought Cressida to Troilus, who was anxiously preparing to confess his love to her for the first time.. Passage two: Pandarus has other intentions; and, while Troilus writes daily letters with increasing love, he contrives the means of an interview. Seeking out Deiphobus, the brother of Troilus, he tells him that Cressida is in danger of violence from Polyphete, and asks protection for her. Deiphobus gladly complies, promises the protection of Hector and Helen, and goes to invite Cressida to dinner on the morrow. Meantime Pandarus instructs Troilus to go to the house of Deiphobus, plead an access of his fever for remaining all night, and keep his chamber next day. “Lo,” says the crafty promoter of love, borrowing a phrase from the hunting-field; “Lo, hold thee at thy tristre close, and I shall well the deer unto thy bowe drive.” Unsuspicious of stratagem, Cressida comes to dinner; and at table, Helen, Pandarus, and others, praise the absent Troilus, until “her heart laughs” for very pride that she has the love of such a knight. After dinner they speak of Cressida’s business; all confirm Deiphobus’ assurances of protection and aid; and Pandarus suggests that, since Troilus is there, Cressida shall herself tell him her case. Helen and Deiphobus alone accompany Pandarus to Troilus’ chamber; there Troilus produces some documents relating to the public weal, which Hector has sent for his opinion; Helen and Deiphobus, engrossed in perusal and discussion, roam out of the chamber, by a stair, into the garden; while Pandarus goes down to the hall, and, pretending that his brother and Helen are still with Troilus, brings Cressida to her lover. The Second Book leaves Pandarus whispering in his niece’s ear counsel to be merciful and kind to her lover, that hath for her such pain; while Troilus lies “in a kankerdort,” hearing the whispering without, and wondering what he shall say for this “was the first time that he should her pray of love; O! mighty God! what shall he say?”. Passage one: Pandarus has other intentions; and, while Troilus writes daily letters with increasing love, he contrives the means of an interview. Seeking out Deiphobus, the brother of Troilus, he tells him that Cressida is in danger of violence from Polyphete, and asks protection for her. Deiphobus gladly complies, promises the protection of Hector and Helen, and goes to invite Cressida to dinner on the morrow. Meantime Pandarus instructs Troilus to go to the house of Deiphobus, plead an access of his fever for remaining all night, and keep his chamber next day. “Lo,” says the crafty promoter of love, borrowing a phrase from the hunting-field; “Lo, hold thee at thy tristre close, and I shall well the deer unto thy bowe drive.” Unsuspicious of stratagem, Cressida comes to dinner; and at table, Helen, Pandarus, and others, praise the absent Troilus, until “her heart laughs” for very pride that she has the love of such a knight. After dinner they speak of Cressida’s business; all confirm Deiphobus’ assurances of protection and aid; and Pandarus suggests that, since Troilus is there, Cressida shall herself tell him her case. Helen and Deiphobus alone accompany Pandarus to Troilus’ chamber; there Troilus produces some documents relating to the public weal, which Hector has sent for his opinion; Helen and Deiphobus, engrossed in perusal and discussion, roam out of the chamber, by a stair, into the garden; while Pandarus goes down to the hall, and, pretending that his brother and Helen are still with Troilus, brings Cressida to her lover. The Second Book leaves Pandarus whispering in his niece’s ear counsel to be merciful and kind to her lover, that hath for her such pain; while Troilus lies “in a kankerdort,” hearing the whispering without, and wondering what he shall say for this “was the first time that he should her pray of love; O! mighty God! what shall he say?”. Passage one: At least, the whisper goes so. Our last King,
Whose image even but now appear’d to us,
Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
Thereto prick’d on by a most emulate pride,
Dar’d to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet,
For so this side of our known world esteem’d him,
Did slay this Fortinbras; who by a seal’d compact,
Well ratified by law and heraldry,
Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
Which he stood seiz’d of, to the conqueror;
Against the which, a moiety competent
Was gaged by our King; which had return’d
To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he been vanquisher; as by the same cov’nant
And carriage of the article design’d,
His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, young Fortinbras,
Of unimproved mettle, hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
Shark’d up a list of lawless resolutes,
For food and diet, to some enterprise
That hath a stomach in’t; which is no other,
As it doth well appear unto our state,
But to recover of us by strong hand
And terms compulsatory, those foresaid lands
So by his father lost. And this, I take it,
Is the main motive of our preparations,
The source of this our watch, and the chief head
Of this post-haste and rummage in the land.. Passage two: In a fierce battle driven by pride, the former King of Denmark defeated the Norwegian King Fortinbras and, through a treaty, claimed Fortinbras's lands. Now, the young Fortinbras, determined to reclaim his father's lost territories, has assembled a band of unruly fighters to launch an attack on Denmark. This looming threat has prompted Denmark to bolster its military defenses and remain on high alert.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: DEMETRIUS.
I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.
Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?
The one I’ll slay, the other slayeth me.
Thou told’st me they were stol’n into this wood,
And here am I, and wode within this wood
Because I cannot meet with Hermia.
Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
HELENA.
You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant,
But yet you draw not iron, for my heart
Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,
And I shall have no power to follow you.
DEMETRIUS.
Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?
Or rather do I not in plainest truth
Tell you I do not, nor I cannot love you?
HELENA.
And even for that do I love you the more.
I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,
The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,
Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,
Unworthy as I am, to follow you.
What worser place can I beg in your love,
(And yet a place of high respect with me)
Than to be usèd as you use your dog?
DEMETRIUS.
Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;
For I am sick when I do look on thee.
HELENA.
And I am sick when I look not on you.. Passage two: In the dense, shadowy woods, Demetrius wandered with a determined look, his eyes scanning the surroundings for any sign of Lysander and Hermia. His mind was set on finding them, but he was not alone in his quest. Helena, driven by her unwavering love for Demetrius, followed him closely, her heart aching with unrequited affection. Despite her constant presence and heartfelt pleas, Demetrius's response was cold and dismissive. He turned to her with a harsh glare, his words cutting through the air like a blade, rejecting her advances without a hint of compassion. Yet, Helena's devotion remained unshaken. She gazed at him with a mixture of longing and sorrow, willing to endure any mistreatment just to be near him. Her love for Demetrius was a flame that refused to be extinguished, even in the face of his relentless rejection. She followed him through the forest, her steps mirroring his, her heart silently hoping that one day, he might see her love and return it. For Helena, the pain of his rebuff was a small price to pay for the chance to be close to the man she adored.. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
FIRST MURDERER.
It was, so please your Highness.
MACBETH.
Well then, now
Have you consider’d of my speeches? Know
That it was he, in the times past, which held you
So under fortune, which you thought had been
Our innocent self? This I made good to you
In our last conference, pass’d in probation with you
How you were borne in hand, how cross’d, the instruments,
Who wrought with them, and all things else that might
To half a soul and to a notion craz’d
Say, “Thus did Banquo.”
FIRST MURDERER.
You made it known to us.
MACBETH.
I did so; and went further, which is now
Our point of second meeting. Do you find
Your patience so predominant in your nature,
That you can let this go? Are you so gospell’d,
To pray for this good man and for his issue,
Whose heavy hand hath bow’d you to the grave,
And beggar’d yours forever?
FIRST MURDERER.
We are men, my liege.
MACBETH.
Ay, in the catalogue ye go for men;
As hounds, and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,
Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept
All by the name of dogs: the valu’d file
Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,
The housekeeper, the hunter, every one
According to the gift which bounteous nature
Hath in him clos’d; whereby he does receive
Particular addition, from the bill
That writes them all alike: and so of men.
Now, if you have a station in the file,
Not i’ th’ worst rank of manhood, say’t;
And I will put that business in your bosoms,
Whose execution takes your enemy off,
Grapples you to the heart and love of us,
Who wear our health but sickly in his life,
Which in his death were perfect.. Passage two: In this scene from 'Macbeth,' Macbeth meets with two hired killers. Macbeth questions their patience and challenges their sense of manhood, urging them to go through with the plan to murder Banquo. He frames the act as a way for them to improve their status and gain his favor.. You have been shown two different passages. As hounds, and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs,
Shoughs, water-rugs, and demi-wolves are clept
All by the name of dogs: the valu’d file
Distinguishes the swift, the slow, the subtle,
The housekeeper, the hunter, every one
According to the gift which bounteous nature
Hath in him clos’d; whereby he does receive
Particular addition, from the bill
That writes them all alike: and so of men.
Now, if you have a station in the file,
Not i’ th’ worst rank of manhood, say’t;

Who wear our health but sickly in his life,

Passage one: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?
FIRST MURDERER.
It was, so please your Highness.
MACBETH.
Well then, now
Have you consider’d of my speeches? Know
That it was he, in the times past, which held you
So under fortune, which you thought had been
Our innocent self? This I made good to you
In our last conference, pass’d in probation with you
How you were borne in hand, how cross’d, the instruments,
Who wrought with them, and all things else that might
To half a soul and to a notion craz’d
Say, “Thus did Banquo.”
FIRST MURDERER.
You made it known to us.
MACBETH.
I did so; and went further, which is now
Our point of second meeting. Do you find
Your patience so predominant in your nature,
That you can let this go? Are you so gospell’d,
To pray for this good man and for his issue,
Whose heavy hand hath bow’d you to the grave,
And beggar’d yours forever?
FIRST MURDERER.
We are men, my liege.

Passage one: Oft, when the world imagine women stray,
The Sylphs thro' mystic mazes guide their way,
Thro' all the giddy circle they pursue,
And old impertinence expel by new.
What tender maid but must a victim fall
To one man's treat, but for another's ball?
When Florio speaks what virgin could withstand,
If gentle Damon did not squeeze her hand?
With varying vanities, from ev'ry part,
They shift the moving Toyshop of their heart;
Where wigs with wigs, with sword-knots sword-knots strive,
Beaux banish beaux, and coaches coaches drive.
This erring mortals Levity may call;
Oh blind to truth! the Sylphs contrive it all.
Of these am I, who thy protection claim,
A watchful sprite, and Ariel is my name.
Late, as I rang'd the crystal wilds of air,
In the clear Mirror of thy ruling Star
I saw, alas! some dread event impend,
Ere to the main this morning sun descend,
But heav'n reveals not what, or how, or where:
Warn'd by the Sylph, oh pious maid, beware!
This to disclose is all thy guardian can:
Beware of all, but most beware of Man!"
He said; when Shock, who thought she slept too long,
Leap'd up, and wak'd his mistress with his tongue.
'T was then, Belinda, if report say true,
Thy eyes first open'd on a Billet-doux;
Wounds, Charms, and Ardors were no sooner read,
But all the Vision vanish'd from thy head.. Passage two: In a world where magical spirits known as Sylphs guide women's behavior, these ethereal beings play a crucial role in protecting them from unwanted advances. The Sylphs cleverly distract women to prevent them from falling for men's charms. Ariel, one of these protective spirits, appears to Belinda, the protagonist, with a grave warning. Ariel urges Belinda to be cautious, especially around men, as danger looms on the horizon. Despite the urgency of the warning, Belinda's attention is soon diverted. She awakens to find a love letter, which completely captures her focus. The letter's allure is so strong that Belinda forgets Ariel's cautionary message, leaving her vulnerable to the very dangers the Sylphs sought to protect her from.. Passage one: Not with more glories, in th' etherial plain,
The Sun first rises o'er the purpled main,
Than, issuing forth, the rival of his beams
Launch'd on the bosom of the silver Thames.
Fair Nymphs, and well-drest Youths around her shone.
But ev'ry eye was fix'd on her alone.
On her white breast a sparkling Cross she wore,
Which Jews might kiss, and Infidels adore.
Her lively looks a sprightly mind disclose,
Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as those:
Favours to none, to all she smiles extends;
Oft she rejects, but never once offends.
Bright as the sun, her eyes the gazers strike,
And, like the sun, they shine on all alike.
Yet graceful ease, and sweetness void of pride,
Might hide her faults, if Belles had faults to hide:
If to her share some female errors fall,
Look on her face, and you'll forget 'em all.
This Nymph, to the destruction of mankind,
Nourish'd two Locks, which graceful hung behind
In equal curls, and well conspir'd to deck
With shining ringlets the smooth iv'ry neck.
Love in these labyrinths his slaves detains,
And mighty hearts are held in slender chains.
With hairy springes we the birds betray,
Slight lines of hair surprise the finny prey,
Fair tresses man's imperial race ensnare,
And beauty draws us with a single hair.
Th' advent'rous Baron the bright locks admir'd;
He saw, he wish'd, and to the prize aspir'd.
Resolv'd to win, he meditates the way,
By force to ravish, or by fraud betray;
For when success a Lover's toil attends,
Few ask, if fraud or force attain'd his ends.. Passage one: 行略定秦地。函谷关有兵守关，不得入。又闻沛公已破咸阳，项羽大怒，使当阳君等击关。项羽遂入，至于戏西。沛公军霸上，未得与项羽相见。沛公左司马曹无伤，使人言于项羽曰：“沛公欲王关中，使子婴为相，珍宝尽有之。”项羽大怒曰：“旦日飨士卒，为击破沛公军！”当是时，项羽兵四十万，在新丰鸿门；沛公兵十万，在霸上。范增说项羽曰：“沛公居山东时，贪于财货，好美姬。今入关，财物无所取，妇女无所幸，此其志不在小。吾令人望其气，皆为龙虎，成五采，此天子气也。急击勿失！”. Passage two: 项羽闻沛公破咸阳，欲王关中，勃然大怒，决意兴兵讨之。范增谏曰：'沛公志不在小物，若不速击，恐失良机。'项羽乃从其言，整军备战，誓欲一举歼灭沛公。时沛公亦知项羽之意，急召诸将，严阵以待。两军对峙，战云密布，天下之势，悬于一线。. You have been shown two different passages. Passage one: 柏子潭，位于深谷之底，潭水深黑，幽邃莫测。潭畔有五龙祠，传皇帝曾于此获雨，灵验非常。潭边有双燕洞、南白鸽洞，洞中奇景，令人叹为观止。潭之西不远，有清澈之让泉，泉水甘冽，清凉宜人。泉旁有一废亭，名曰‘渐入佳境’，虽废而景致犹存。淳熙年间，地方官张商卿等人曾于此题诗，诗情画意，流传至今。. Passage two: 东南有柏子潭。潭在深谷底，延袤亩余，色正深黑。即欧阳公赛龙处，上有五龙祠。皇上初龙飞，屯兵于滁，会旱暵，亲挟雕弓，注矢于潭者三，约三日雨，如期果大雨。及御宝历，为作栏楯护潭，且新其庙。庙侧有时若亭。濂坐亭上，问潭侧双燕洞及其南白鸽洞，以肆穷览，人无知者，乃止。复西行约三里许，有泉泻出于两山之间，分流而下，曰让泉，潺潺清澈，可鉴毛发。傍岸有亭曰“渐入佳境”，今已废，惟四大字勒崖石间。淳熙中郡守张商卿等题名尚存。. Passage one: 晋太元中，武陵人捕鱼为业。缘溪行，忘路之远近。忽逢桃花林，夹岸数百步，中无杂树，芳草鲜美，落英缤纷。渔人甚异之，复前行，欲穷其林。林尽水源，便得一山，山有小口，仿佛若有光。便舍船，从口入。初极狭，才通人。复行数十步，豁然开朗。土地平旷，屋舍俨然，有良田、美池、桑竹之属。阡陌交通，鸡犬相闻。其中往来种作，男女衣着，悉如外人。黄发垂髫，并怡然自乐。见渔人，乃大惊，问所从来。具答之。便要还家，设酒杀鸡作食。村中闻有此人，咸来问讯。自云先世避秦时乱，率妻子邑人来此绝境，不复出焉，遂与外人间隔。问今是何世，乃不知有汉，无论魏晋。此人一一为具言所闻，皆叹惋。余人各复延至其家，皆出酒食。停数日，辞去。此中人语云：“不足为外人道也。”既出，得其船，便扶向路，处处志之。及郡下，诣太守，说如此。太守即遣人随其往，寻向所志，遂迷，不复得路。南阳刘子骥，高尚士也，闻之，欣然规往。未果，寻病终。后遂无问津者。. Passage one: 庆历四年春，滕子京谪守巴陵郡。越明年，政通人和，百废具兴，乃重修岳阳楼，增其旧制，刻唐贤今人诗赋于其上，属予作文以记之。予观夫巴陵胜状，在洞庭一湖。衔远山，吞长江，浩浩汤汤，横无际涯，朝晖夕阴，气象万千，此则岳阳楼之大观也，前人之述备矣。然则北通巫峡，南极潇湘，迁客骚人，多会于此，览物之情，得无异乎？若夫淫雨霏霏，连月不开，阴风怒号，浊浪排空，日星隐曜，山岳潜形，商旅不行，樯倾楫摧，薄暮冥冥，虎啸猿啼。登斯楼也，则有去国怀乡，忧谗畏讥，满目萧然，感极而悲者矣。至若春和景明，波澜不惊，上下天光，一碧万顷，沙鸥翔集，锦鳞游泳，岸芷汀兰，郁郁青青。而或长烟一空，皓月千里，浮光跃金，静影沉璧，渔歌互答，此乐何极！登斯楼也，则有心旷神怡，宠辱偕忘，把酒临风，其喜洋洋者矣。嗟夫！予尝求古仁人之心，或异二者之为，何哉？不以物喜，不以己悲，居庙堂之高则忧其民，处江湖之远则忧其君。是进亦忧，退亦忧。然则何时而乐耶？其必曰“先天下之忧而忧，后天下之乐而乐”乎！噫！微斯人，吾谁与归？时六年九月十五日。. Passage two: 庆历四年春，滕子京谪守巴陵郡。子京至郡，励精图治，政通人和。经一载之功，重修岳阳楼，乃命余为文以记之。余观岳阳楼之壮丽，洞庭湖之浩渺，感慨万千。楼高百尺，俯瞰湖光山色，四时景象，变幻无穷。晴空万里，碧波荡漾，令人心旷神怡；阴云密布，风雨交加，令人忧思难抑。余因景生情，思及古仁人之心态，感慨良多。古仁人不以物喜，不以己悲，心忧天下，志在四方。其精神在于先天下之忧而忧，后天下之乐而乐。余叹曰：若无此等仁人，吾将与谁共鸣乎？. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage one: 环滁皆山也。其西南诸峰，林壑尤美，望之蔚然而深秀者，琅琊也。山行六七里，渐闻水声潺潺，而泻出于两峰之间者，酿泉也。峰回路转，有亭翼然临于泉上者，醉翁亭也。作亭者谁？山之僧智仙也。名之者谁？太守自谓也。太守与客来饮于此，饮少辄醉，而年又最高，故自号曰醉翁也。醉翁之意不在酒，在乎山水之间也。山水之乐，得之心而寓之酒也。若夫日出而林霏开，云归而岩穴暝，晦明变化者，山间之朝暮也。野芳发而幽香，佳木秀而繁阴，风霜高洁，水落而石出者，山间之四时也。朝而往，暮而归，四时之景不同，而乐亦无穷也。至于负者歌于途，行者休于树，前者呼，后者应，伛偻提携，往来而不绝者，滁人游也。临溪而渔，溪深而鱼肥，酿泉为酒，泉香而酒洌，山肴野蔌，杂然而前陈者，太守宴也。宴酣之乐，非丝非竹，射者中，弈者胜，觥筹交错，起坐而喧哗者，众宾欢也。苍颜白发，颓然乎其间者，太守醉也。已而夕阳在山，人影散乱，太守归而宾客从也。树林阴翳，鸣声上下，游人去而禽鸟乐也。然而禽鸟知山林之乐，而不知人之乐；人知从太守游而乐，而不知太守之乐其乐也。醉能同其乐，醒能述以文者，太守也。太守谓谁？庐陵欧阳修也。. Passage one: 余告之曰：其形也，翩若惊鸿，婉若游龙。荣曜秋菊，华茂春松。髣髴兮若轻云之蔽月，飘飖兮若流风之回雪。远而望之，皎若太阳升朝霞；迫而察之，灼若芙蕖出渌波。穠纤得衷，修短合度。肩若削成，腰如约素。延颈秀项，皓质呈露。芳泽无加，铅华弗御。云髻峨峨，修眉联娟。丹唇外朗，皓齿内鲜。明眸善睐，靥辅承权。瓌姿艳逸，仪静体闲。柔情绰态，媚于语言。奇服旷世，骨像应图。披罗衣之璀粲兮，珥瑶碧之华琚。戴金翠之首饰，缀明珠以耀躯。践远游之文履，曳雾绡之轻裾。微幽兰之芳蔼兮，步踟蹰于山隅。于是忽焉纵体，以遨以嬉。左倚采旄，右荫桂旗。攘皓腕于神浒兮，采湍濑之玄芝。. Passage two: 有一女子，容貌绝世，气质非凡。其形态之美，若鸿鹤轻盈，若游龙翩翩。面如桃花，光彩照人，姿态潇洒，令人心醉。其服饰精美绝伦，绫罗绸缎，华丽无比。佩饰璀璨，珠光宝气，举手投足之间，尽显高雅气质。其步履轻盈，若风拂柳，其笑容温婉，若春风拂面。此女子之美，世间罕见，令人叹为观止。其容貌、气质、服饰，皆为绝代佳人，令人心驰神往。. Passage two: 余告之曰：其形也，翩若惊鸿，婉若游龙。荣曜秋菊，华茂春松。髣髴兮若轻云之蔽月，飘飖兮若流风之回雪。远而望之，皎若太阳升朝霞；迫而察之，灼若芙蕖出渌波。穠纤得衷，修短合度。肩若削成，腰如约素。延颈秀项，皓质呈露。芳泽无加，铅华弗御。云髻峨峨，修眉联娟。丹唇外朗，皓齿内鲜。明眸善睐，靥辅承权。瓌姿艳逸，仪静体闲。柔情绰态，媚于语言。奇服旷世，骨像应图。披罗衣之璀粲兮，珥瑶碧之华琚。戴金翠之首饰，缀明珠以耀躯。践远游之文履，曳雾绡之轻裾。微幽兰之芳蔼兮，步踟蹰于山隅。于是忽焉纵体，以遨以嬉。左倚采旄，右荫桂旗。攘皓腕于神浒兮，采湍濑之玄芝。. Passage one: 天地之间，正气充盈，形态万千，然其本质一也。正气之显，或为山川之壮丽，或为日月之光辉，皆天地自然之象也。人间之正气，化为浩然之气，充塞宇宙，无所不在。古往今来，仁人志士之高尚行为，皆赖正气而成，赋予其不朽之生命力。或为国捐躯，或修身齐家，皆正气之所致也。余虽命途多舛，身陷囹圄，然心怀正气，未尝一日懈怠。对未来之信心，亦未曾动摇。正气之存，乃正义与道德之体现，高尚人格之弘扬也。余愿以此心，追求正气，虽千难万险，亦不改其志。天地正气，永存不灭，吾辈当以此为鉴，砥砺前行。. Passage two: 天地有正气，杂然赋流形。下则为河岳，上则为日星。于人曰浩然，沛乎塞苍冥。皇路当清夷，含和吐明庭。时穷节乃见，一一垂丹青。在齐太史简，在晋董狐笔。在秦张良椎，在汉苏武节。为严将军头，为嵇侍中血。为张睢阳齿，为颜常山舌。或为辽东帽，清操厉冰雪。或为出师表，鬼神泣壮烈。或为渡江楫，慷慨吞胡羯。或为击贼笏，逆竖头破裂。是气所磅礴，凛烈万古存。当其贯日月，生死安足论。地维赖以立，天柱赖以尊。三纲实系命，道义为之根。嗟予遘阳九，隶也实不力。楚囚缨其冠，传车送穷北。鼎镬甘如饴，求之不可得。阴房阗鬼火，春院閟天黑。(阗 一作：阒)牛骥同一皂，鸡栖凤凰食。一朝蒙雾露，分作沟中瘠。如此再寒暑，百沴自辟易。嗟哉沮洳场，为我安乐国。岂有他缪巧，阴阳不能贼。顾此耿耿在，仰视浮云白。悠悠我心悲，苍天曷有极。哲人日已远，典刑在夙昔。风檐展书读，古道照颜色。. Passage one: 于是张良至军门见樊哙。樊哙曰：“今日之事何如？”良曰：“甚急！今者项庄拔剑舞，其意常在沛公也。”哙曰：“此迫矣！臣请入，与之同命。”哙即带剑拥盾入军门。交戟之卫士欲止不内，樊哙侧其盾以撞，卫士仆地，哙遂入，披帷西向立，瞋目视项王，头发上指，目眦尽裂。项王按剑而跽曰：“客何为者？”张良曰：“沛公之参乘樊哙者也。”项王曰：“壮士！赐之卮酒。”则与斗卮酒。哙拜谢，起，立而饮之。项王曰：“赐之彘肩。”则与一生彘肩。樊哙覆其盾于地，加彘肩上，拔剑切而啖之。项王曰：“壮士！能复饮乎？”樊哙曰：“臣死且不避，卮酒安足辞！夫秦王有虎狼之心，杀人如不能举，刑人如恐不胜，天下皆叛之。怀王与诸将约曰：‘先破秦入咸阳者王之。’今沛公先破秦入咸阳，毫毛不敢有所近，封闭宫室，还军霸上，以待大王来。故遣将守关者，备他盗出入与非常也。劳苦而功高如此，未有封侯之赏，而听细说，欲诛有功之人，此亡秦之续耳。窃为大王不取也！”项王未有以应，曰：“坐。”樊哙从良坐。坐须臾，沛公起如厕，因招樊哙出。. Passage one: 秦始皇承六代之雄功，强力统治，统一天下。废先王之道，行专制之政，焚书坑儒，削弱地方，除异己。南征百越，北筑长城，御匈奴，建强大中央集权之国。始皇以关中之地固若金汤，建坚固都城及防御体系，谓子孙可永世为王。. Passage two: 及至始皇，奋六世之余烈，振长策而御宇内，吞二周而亡诸侯，履至尊而制六合，执敲扑而鞭笞天下，威振四海。南取百越之地，以为桂林、象郡；百越之君，俯首系颈，委命下吏。乃使蒙恬北筑长城而守藩篱，却匈奴七百余里。胡人不敢南下而牧马，士不敢弯弓而报怨。于是废先王之道，焚百家之言，以愚黔首；隳名城，杀豪杰，收天下之兵，聚之咸阳，销锋镝，铸以为金人十二，以弱天下之民。然后践华为城，因河为池，据亿丈之城，临不测之渊，以为固。良将劲弩守要害之处，信臣精卒陈利兵而谁何。天下已定，始皇之心，自以为关中之固，金城千里，子孙帝王万世之业也。. Passage one: 昔有一女子，嫁于府吏，初时夫妻和美，情意绵绵。然府吏之母不喜此女子，常以苛责相待，女子心中苦楚，难以言表。日复一日，女子备受煎熬，终至忍无可忍，泪眼婆娑，向府吏提出欲归家之意。府吏闻之，心中大痛，极力反对，然母命难违，终不能改其意。府吏无奈，唯有叹息，女子亦心如刀割，泪如雨下。女子临别之时，回首往昔岁月，心中无限遗憾，叹道：“昔日欢愉，今成泡影，吾心何堪？未来之路，茫茫无期，吾命多舛。”言罢，女子含泪离去，府吏目送其远去，心中悲痛难抑。此后，府吏每念及此事，心中愧疚，悔恨不已，然事已至此，唯有长叹。. Passage two: “十三能织素，十四学裁衣。十五弹箜篌，十六诵诗书。十七为君妇，心中常苦悲。君既为府吏，守节情不移。贱妾留空房，相见常日稀。鸡鸣入机织，夜夜不得息。三日断五匹，大人故嫌迟。非为织作迟，君家妇难为！妾不堪驱使，徒留无所施。便可白公姥，及时相遣归。” 府吏得闻之，堂上启阿母：“儿已薄禄相，幸复得此妇。结发同枕席，黄泉共为友。共事二三年，始尔未为久。女行无偏斜，何意致不厚。” 阿母谓府吏：“何乃太区区！此妇无礼节，举动自专由。吾意久怀忿，汝岂得自由！东家有贤女，自名秦罗敷。可怜体无比，阿母为汝求。便可速遣之，遣去慎莫留！” 府吏长跪告：“伏惟启阿母。今若遣此妇，终老不复取！” 阿母得闻之，槌床便大怒：“小子无所畏，何敢助妇语！吾已失恩义，会不相从许！” 府吏默无声，再拜还入户。举言谓新妇，哽咽不能语：“我自不驱卿，逼迫有阿母。卿但暂还家，吾今且报府。不久当归还，还必相迎取。以此下心意，慎勿违吾语。” 新妇谓府吏：“勿复重纷纭。往昔初阳岁，谢家来贵门。奉事循公姥，进止敢自专？昼夜勤作息，伶俜萦苦辛。谓言无罪过，供养卒大恩；仍更被驱遣，何言复来还！妾有绣腰襦，葳蕤自生光；红罗复斗帐，四角垂香囊；箱帘六七十，绿碧青丝绳，物物各自异，种种在其中。人贱物亦鄙，不足迎后人，留待作遗施，于今无会因。时时为安慰，久久莫相忘！”. You have been shown two different passages. One of the passages is generated by a LLM, while the other is written by real people. Which of the above passages is most likely not generated by AI?

Passage two: “十三能织素，十四学裁衣。十五弹箜篌，十六诵诗书。十七为君妇，心中常苦悲。君既为府吏，守节情不移。贱妾留空房，相见常日稀。鸡鸣入机织，夜夜不得息。三日断五匹，大人故嫌迟。非为织作迟，君家妇难为！妾不堪驱使，徒留无所施。便可白公姥，及时相遣归。” 府吏得闻之，堂上启阿母：“儿已薄禄相，幸复得此妇。结发同枕席，黄泉共为友。共事二三年，始尔未为久。女行无偏斜，何意致不厚。” 阿母谓府吏：“何乃太区区！此妇无礼节，举动自专由。吾意久怀忿，汝岂得自由！东家有贤女，自名秦罗敷。可怜体无比，阿母为汝求。便可速遣之，遣去慎莫留！” 府吏长跪告：“伏惟启阿母。今若遣此妇，终老不复取！” 阿母得闻之，槌床便大怒：“小子无所畏，何敢助妇语！吾已失恩义，会不相从许！” 府吏默无声，再拜还入户。举言谓新妇，哽咽不能语：“我自不驱卿，逼迫有阿母。卿但暂还家，吾今且报府。不久当归还，还必相迎取。以此下心意，慎勿违吾语。” 新妇谓府吏：“勿复重纷纭。往昔初阳岁，谢家来贵门。奉事循公姥，进止敢自专？昼夜勤作息，伶俜萦苦辛。谓言无罪过，供养卒大恩；仍更被驱遣，何言复来还！妾有绣腰襦，葳蕤自生光；红罗复斗帐，四角垂香囊；箱帘六七十，绿碧青丝绳，物物各自异，种种在其中。人贱物亦鄙，不足迎后人，留待作遗施，于今无会因。时时为安慰，久久莫相忘！”. Passage one: 六王毕，四海一，蜀山兀，阿房出。覆压三百余里，隔离天日。骊山北构而西折，直走咸阳。二川溶溶，流入宫墙。五步一楼，十步一阁；廊腰缦回，檐牙高啄；各抱地势，钩心斗角。盘盘焉，囷囷焉，蜂房水涡，矗不知其几千万落。长桥卧波，未云何龙？复道行空，不霁何虹？高低冥迷，不知西东。歌台暖响，春光融融；舞殿冷袖，风雨凄凄。一日之内，一宫之间，而气候不齐。
妃嫔媵嫱，王子皇孙，辞楼下殿，辇来于秦。朝歌夜弦，为秦宫人。明星荧荧，开妆镜也；绿云扰扰，梳晓鬟也；渭流涨腻，弃脂水也；烟斜雾横，焚椒兰也。雷霆乍惊，宫车过也；辘辘远听，杳不知其所之也。一肌一容，尽态极妍，缦立远视，而望幸焉。有不见者，三十六年。燕赵之收藏，韩魏之经营，齐楚之精英，几世几年，剽掠其人，倚叠如山。一旦不能有，输来其间。鼎铛玉石，金块珠砾，弃掷逦迤，秦人视之，亦不甚惜。. Passage two: 阿房宫者，秦之极盛也。其宫殿巍峨，楼阁重重，金碧辉煌，光耀四方。宫中雕梁画栋，珠帘玉户，奇珍异宝，琳琅满目。其规模之大，东西五里，南北千步，宫墙高耸，气势恢宏。宫内庭院深深，花木扶疏，池水潺潺，鸟语花香。宫人如云，衣香鬓影，歌舞升平，乐声悠扬。秦王居其中，享尽人间富贵，奢华无度。然则，富贵奢靡，终为祸端。贪婪之心，侵占之欲，渐生于宫中。秦王朝之盛，亦因之而衰。阿房宫之美景，终为灰烬，秦王朝之富庶，亦成过眼云烟。盛极而衰，古今一理，阿房宫之兴衰，亦为后世之鉴。. Passage one: 乾隆三十九年冬，余自京城启程，途经数地，终至泰山。初发京城，天寒地冻，风雪交加，行路艰难。至济南，稍得歇息，复行数日，抵达泰山脚下。泰山巍峨，云雾缭绕，登山之路蜿蜒曲折，石阶陡峭，行者多喘息不止。余沿途观景，见山石嶙峋，古木参天，冰雪覆盖，景色壮丽。途中多有古刹庙宇，香火鼎盛，游人如织。至中天门，已觉力竭，然不敢稍歇，继续攀登。至南天门，天色将明，寒风刺骨，然心志愈坚。终至玉皇顶，东方既白，日出之景，蔚为壮观。红日初升，霞光万丈，照耀山川，万物皆披金色。顶上有古建筑数座，皆雕梁画栋，气势恢宏。石刻遍布，字迹遒劲，述古人登临之感。泰山之巅，俯瞰四野，群山连绵，河流蜿蜒，尽收眼底。山中石多奇形怪状，或如兽，或如人，千姿百态。树木苍翠，枝叶繁茂，冬日虽寒，仍有生机。冰雪覆盖，晶莹剔透，宛如玉带缠绕山间。余立于山巅，感天地之浩渺，叹人生之渺小，心中感慨万千。. Passage two: 余以乾隆三十九年十二月，自京师乘风雪，历齐河、长清，穿泰山西北谷，越长城之限，至于泰安。是月丁未，与知府朱孝纯子颍由南麓登。四十五里，道皆砌石为磴，其级七千有余。泰山正南面有三谷。中谷绕泰安城下，郦道元所谓环水也。余始循以入，道少半，越中岭，复循西谷，遂至其巅。古时登山，循东谷入，道有天门。东谷者，古谓之天门溪水，余所不至也。今所经中岭及山巅，崖限当道者，世皆谓之天门云。道中迷雾冰滑，磴几不可登。及既上，苍山负雪，明烛天南。望晚日照城郭，汶水、徂徕如画，而半山居雾若带然。 戊申晦，五鼓，与子颍坐日观亭，待日出。大风扬积雪击面。亭东自足下皆云漫。稍见云中白若樗蒱数十立者，山也。极天云一线异色，须臾成五采。日上，正赤如丹，下有红光动摇承之。或曰，此东海也。回视日观以西峰，或得日或否，绛皓驳色，而皆若偻。 亭西有岱祠，又有碧霞元君祠。皇帝行宫在碧霞元君祠东。是日观道中石刻，自唐显庆以来；其远古刻尽漫失。僻不当道者，皆不及往。 山多石，少土。石苍黑色，多平方，少圜。少杂树，多松，生石罅，皆平顶。冰雪，无瀑水，无鸟兽音迹。至日观数里内无树，而雪与人膝齐。 桐城姚鼐记。. Passage two: 乾隆三十九年冬，余自京城启程，途经数地，终至泰山。初发京城，天寒地冻，风雪交加，行路艰难。至济南，稍得歇息，复行数日，抵达泰山脚下。泰山巍峨，云雾缭绕，登山之路蜿蜒曲折，石阶陡峭，行者多喘息不止。余沿途观景，见山石嶙峋，古木参天，冰雪覆盖，景色壮丽。途中多有古刹庙宇，香火鼎盛，游人如织。至中天门，已觉力竭，然不敢稍歇，继续攀登。至南天门，天色将明，寒风刺骨，然心志愈坚。终至玉皇顶，东方既白，日出之景，蔚为壮观。红日初升，霞光万丈，照耀山川，万物皆披金色。顶上有古建筑数座，皆雕梁画栋，气势恢宏。石刻遍布，字迹遒劲，述古人登临之感。泰山之巅，俯瞰四野，群山连绵，河流蜿蜒，尽收眼底。山中石多奇形怪状，或如兽，或如人，千姿百态。树木苍翠，枝叶繁茂，冬日虽寒，仍有生机。冰雪覆盖，晶莹剔透，宛如玉带缠绕山间。余立于山巅，感天地之浩渺，叹人生之渺小，心中感慨万千。.
